<p>The significance of conducting research is to communicate and share the research findings. If you do not disseminate the findings of your study, then nobody will know what the outcome of the study was. There are various ways of communicating the research findings. They include:</p>
<ul>
<li>A written report for academic purposes, for example, a dissertation or a thesis, which are a requirement in the obtaining of a certain academic level.</li>
<li>A written report prepared for managers and policy implementers (some of whom have no knowledge of research methodology). In such reports you need to have a very clear and succinct report without the academic jargons.</li>
<li>A written report sent as an article for publication in refereed journals.</li>
<li>Presentations of the research findings in workshops, seminars and conferences.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishop's Computers</p>
<p>Bishop's Computers</p>
<p>Bishop's Computers
Page 109 of 185
Bishop's Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-research-process">The Research Process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-research-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260119-b2c911db.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg"></p>
<p>You will now look at what you need to have in a written research report.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-title">The Title<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-title" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The title should be an accurate reflection of the research carried out</li>
<li>It needs to be both meaningful and brief</li>
<li>It should not exceed fifteen words (Brink, 1996)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abstract">Abstract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abstract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The abstract is a very brief summary of the study that includes the purpose of the study, methodology and the major research findings. It should not be longer than one page.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the introduction you need to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Introduce the reader to the problem to be dealt with.</li>
<li>Briefly, but clearly, explain the purpose of the study.</li>
<li>Emphasise the importance of the study.</li>
<li>Introduce the key concepts.</li>
<li>State clearly the hypothesis as well as the objectives or research questions of the study.</li>
<li>Describe the nature of the research study and the context within which the study has been carried out.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="background-information">Background Information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#background-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Here you have to explain where the study took place and expound on any special circumstances of the study and study area.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="literature-review">Literature Review<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#literature-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The literature review provides an overview of current knowledge of the problem under research. The researcher should be able to show a grasp of the theory applications and apply the knowledge to the research.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-methodology">The Methodology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-methodology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Here, you provide information on how the research was carried out. Include enough details to enable another researcher to replicate your research. The methods section incorporates the following aspects:</p>
<p>(i) Subjects, respondents or participants
(ii) The task and the material or instruments used. This should include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Description of all types of activities that the participants were asked to perform, for example, filling in a questionnaire, participating in a focus group discussion.</li>
<li>A list of materials and/or instruments used. Give the main characteristics of the questionnaire, for example open-ended, closed questions and so on.</li>
<li>Description of the considerations, which led to this choice and how validity and reliability were ensured.</li>
<li>All questionnaires or interview schedules should be included in an appendix.</li>
</ul>
<p>(iii) The research design and strategy. Here you have to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Specify the chosen design.</li>
<li>Outline and explain choices which lay behind strategy decisions.</li>
<li>Analyse the data obtained.</li>
<li>Give an account of the methods used to analyse data.</li>
<li>If a statistical design was used, discuss the statistical tests applied to the obtained data to test the various hypotheses.</li>
<li>Explain procedures for handling missing data.</li>
<li>Justify the validity and reliability of the scores.</li>
<li>Outline the reasons why specific statistical tests were used.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishop's Computers
Page 110 of 185
Bishop's Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="results">Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The results section presents the findings and involves the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>The main results from the data analysis.</li>
<li>If a quantitative study was done, tables, graphs and diagrams and the outcomes of statistical tests. In a qualitative study, findings are usually presented in terms of the themes, which emerged from the data and, by way of substantiation and illustration, examples of raw data will be given. For example, direct quotes from an interview transcription, or accounts of observation.</li>
<li>In quantitative studies you must also give the name of any statistical test used as well as the value of the calculated statistics and its significance. Accuracy and conciseness must be adhered to throughout.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="discussion">Discussion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#discussion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>According to Brink (1996) the discussion of the study incorporates the following elements:</p>
<ul>
<li>An interpretation of the findings, with specific reference to validity and reliability. A well developed discussion makes sense of the research results, and must be presented in precise and concise language. In the discussion section, you have to re-state the research questions and hypotheses, and discuss the results with reference to these questions or hypotheses in the order they were posed.</li>
<li>Conclusions related to questions raised in the introduction of the study.</li>
<li>Study limitations. Here the limitations of the study should be identified and you should defend the validity of the findings in the light of these limitations. Limitations include factors such as the inherent weakness in the sampling method, faulty designs and controls, weaknesses in the methods used to collect data and so forth. Here you have the opportunity to recommend ways to minimise or eliminate the limitations of the current study and to offer alternative methodology or improvements of the methods of the study presented.</li>
<li>Generalisations of the research findings. Indicate whether you found what you had expected and how the present results relate to previous research.</li>
</ul>
<p>Connect the findings with similar studies. If any unexpected, inconclusive or contradictory results were obtained, discuss possible reasons for such outcomes.</p>
<ul>
<li>Suggestions and recommendations. Here you have to relate your findings to the questions raised in the introduction. In addition, if you came up with any recommendations as a result of your study, this is the place to state them. You may also give some suggestions concerning further research.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="references-and-bibliography">References and Bibliography<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#references-and-bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Present your references and bibliography in the standard manner.</p>
<p>You can follow the way these are given in your student handbook, or follow any other format specific to your institution. Whatever format you are using, however, you need to remember that all your entries should be made in a consistent manner. Check that the names of authors included in your reference list, are actually mentioned within the text.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-4-developing-a-proposal-introduction">Section 4: Developing a Proposal Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-4-developing-a-proposal-introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this section you will learn how to write a research proposal, or a research protocol as some researchers prefer to call it, either for funding or for academic purposes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>By the end of this section, you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe a research proposal</li>
<li>List three purposes of developing a research proposal</li>
<li>Identify the major contents of a research proposal</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="research-proposal">Research Proposal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#research-proposal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-is-a-research-proposal">What is a research proposal?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-a-research-proposal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is important to be able to define what a research proposal is before you learn how to develop it. A research proposal has several definitions.</p>
<p>However, you will only look at one of them. According to Bernard and Morrison (1990: 15), 'A research proposal is a detailed statement of what you intend to do, why you want to do it and how you will go about it'.</p>
<p>This definition shows that a research proposal is a statement that outlines the what, why and how of your study. It gives an indication of whether you are able to implement the research following the intended research design and methods you selected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="why-develop-a-research-proposal">Why develop a research proposal?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#why-develop-a-research-proposal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A research proposal helps the researcher:</p>
<ul>
<li>To sharpen their thoughts and the research methodology.</li>
<li>To allow others to examine the research project and its methods.</li>
<li>To get clearance and authority from the government and ethics committee to carry out the research.</li>
</ul>
<p>Despite the important role played by a research proposal, at times it is a difficult hurdle to overcome, particularly to new researchers. When developing a research proposal, you need to be patient as you might be required to re-write the proposal several times. This is a very common occurrence with all researches and you, as a student researcher, should not feel discouraged. It should, instead, give you the motivation to clarify and refine your thoughts and ideas. Your peers provide a good resource in such circumstances so you should ask them to read through your proposal and give you their comments.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-should-a-research-proposal-contain">What should a research proposal contain?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-should-a-research-proposal-contain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The content of a research proposal varies a lot. This is due to the fact that each institution, for example a college, hospital or an ethics committee, has its own guidelines to be followed by those seeking its approval. Even sponsors of research projects have their own approaches. Therefore, you as a researcher will need to be aware of such variations and abide by them.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Project title.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Your name and index number.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Name, titles and designations of your supervisor, tutor or lecturer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Name of the department, and college or university.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Statement of the research problem.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rationale or justification of research.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Brief relevant literature review.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Research methodology or design.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Methods of data analysis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ethical considerations taken into account.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preparation of study report.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Timeline of the study.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Study budget.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Appendices.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Your Curriculum Vitae (CV) where applicable. You as an upgrading nurse have several years of work experience that you should include in your CV.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>In conclusion, a research proposal is a very important part of the research process. It is a detailed statement outlining the major components of the research process. It is what you intend to do in your research, why you want to do it and how you will go about it in achieving your set research objectives.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="time-line-or-time-schedule">Time Line or Time Schedule<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#time-line-or-time-schedule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>One of the items you will need to include in your proposal is a schedule for your study. The activities you intend to undertake during the process of your study are summarised in a table format. The time lines, activity schedule or Ghent chart are some of the names used to refer to this kind of a table. It has the activities on the first column and on the first row is the duration of time that is required to complete the tasks. The researcher should clearly write the details of the activities which will then be summarised in the time line or Ghent chart.</p>
<p>Bishop's Computers
Page 111 of 185
Bishop's Computers</p>
<p>Bishop's Computers
Page 112 of 185
Bishop's Computers</p>
<p>Time Line of Study</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Activity</th><th>Jan</th><th>Feb</th><th>March</th><th>April</th><th>May</th><th>June</th><th>July</th><th>Sept</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Identifying research topic</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Formulating research objectives</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Justification of study</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Literature review</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Research methodology</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Method of data collection</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Conducting a pre-test</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Data collection/ presentation</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Data analysis and Interpretation</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Report preparation/typing</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>From this table it is easily seen that you intend to start your research in January and end it in September. On the other hand, the data will be collected in June.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-budget">Study Budget<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-budget" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Another item that you are expected to have in your proposal is a proposed budget. You must be careful to include all expenses that you are likely to incur during the research otherwise, you may find yourself unable to complete your research due to lack of funds.</p>
<p>From the following illustration of a proposed budget, note the budget items that you need to include. The amount indicated in the right hand column may vary depending on the quantities you need.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Study Budget</th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Budget item</td><td>Quantity</td><td>Cost per item (in Kshs)</td><td>Total amount (in Kshs)</td></tr><tr><td>Stationery</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>1,000</td></tr><tr><td>Photocopying</td><td>100pages</td><td>3</td><td>3,000</td></tr><tr><td>Typing</td><td>300pages</td><td>10</td><td>3,000</td></tr><tr><td>Binding</td><td>10 copies</td><td>50</td><td>500</td></tr><tr><td>Research assistant</td><td>5 for 3 days</td><td>100 per day</td><td>1,500</td></tr><tr><td>Travelling allowance</td><td>1 person for 25 days</td><td>100 per day</td><td>2,500</td></tr><tr><td>Books, journals and internet services</td><td>Estimate</td><td>Estimate</td><td>5,000</td></tr><tr><td>Computer or printer</td><td>1 set</td><td>70,000</td><td>70,000</td></tr><tr><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td></tr><tr><td>Total</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>86,500</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-limitation">Study Limitation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-limitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Limitations of the study should be identified and the researcher should defend the validity of the findings in the light of such limitations. Limitations may include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Factors such as the inherent weakness in the sampling method, faulty designs and controls, weaknesses in the methods used to collect data and so on.</li>
<li>Time factor due to pressure of work.</li>
<li>Expenses involved if grant is not secured.</li>
<li>Possibility that some of the respondents may not agree to participate in the study.</li>
<li>Diverse spread of the target population, which may hinder easy access to respondents.</li>
</ul>
<p>The researcher has the opportunity to recommend ways to minimise or eliminate the limitations of the current study or to offer alternative methodology or improvements of the methods of the study presented.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assignment-conducting-research-or-field-work">Assignment: Conducting Research or Field Work<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assignment-conducting-research-or-field-work" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For this assignment you will put into practice the various aspects of the research process that you have covered in the previous sections of this unit. The skills and knowledge you have gained are now to be put into practice in the field.</p>
<p>Therefore, your next step is to identify a research topic, and following the research process you have learnt, to conduct a research field study. You will do this with the guidance of your research project supervisor.</p>
<p>Bishop's Computers

Bishop's Computers</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="kenya-medical-training-college">KENYA MEDICAL TRAINING COLLEGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kenya-medical-training-college" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Guidelines for research proposals, research reports, dissertations and case studies</p>
<p>May 2024</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="foreword">FOREWORD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#foreword" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Research is a fundamental aspect of the mandate of the Kenya Medical Training College (KMTC) and the successful completion of the research requirements for each academic program is a prerequisite for graduation from KMTC. The college is a state corporation in the training and research category of state corporations. Over the last decade the college has steadily advanced its commitment to research and innovation, among both staff and students. Research guidelines provide guidance on â€˜how toâ€™ aspects of academic research practice. These guidelines are designed to provide direction to students, faculty, supervisors (internal and external), librarians, heads of departments, principals and all persons involved in conducting or supporting scientific research at the college.</p>
<p>The guideline provides the key elements that should be included in a research proposal, a research dissertation and a case study. All students and staff are required to adhere as closely as possible to the guideline. This is important for standardisation of research products in the academic domain. We recognize that research practice is dynamic, and that there may be discipline-specific variations in some clinical or research procedures. In the event of this variation, the research office will review and provide support, which may include engaging stakeholders in the research space to provide the necessary support to the researchers.</p>
<p>This guideline is user-friendly, and it will aid both staff and students to navigate the research process. I note that this 2024 edition has incorporated the lessons learnt from previous editions. We expect that it will enhance the research experience and support high quality research outputs.</p>
<p>I thank all the members of the college research advisory committee, who have collaboratively reviewed the previous edition and have participated in the development of this updated resource.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260119-b1acf3ce.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg"></p>
<p>Dr. Kelly Oluoch</p>
<p>CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER</p>
<p>iii</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preface">PREFACE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preface" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The 2024 edition of the research guidelines replaces the previous editions from the date of signature. In this edition, there are new additions such as the copyright statement, the role of the library, students and supervisors, ethics courses, plagiarism checks, checks for unethical use of artificial intelligence, tracking research supervision and word/page limits for proposals, dissertations and case studies. It also considers the entire research pathway from the choice of topic to the dissemination of the findings.</p>
<p>This edition has been developed through a consultative and iterative process. I thank the research office, led by the Deputy Registrar, Research, Ms Eglah Kigen and Mr Francis Gachanja, along with the members of the College Research Advisory Committee led by Dr John Aswani, and peer reviewers like Dr Munyoki Nyamai and Dr Anne Mwendwa for input into the document.</p>
<p>This document will apply to all students, all courses, all faculty and all campuses. Should you have any enquiries or comments, contact the research office via <a href="mailto:research@kmtc.ac.ke" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">research@kmtc.ac.ke</a>.</p>
<p>f. Dr Nyawira Mwangi
DEPUTY DIRECTOR ACADEMIC</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Research is conventionally defined as the process of systematic inquiry into a defined area of interest, using appropriate methods for acquisition, analysis and interpretation of data. The research guidelines have been developed to guide the development of research competencies, proposals, projects, case studies and outputs at the Kenya Medical Training College (KMTC).</p>
<p>Some of the common challenges encountered along the research pipeline include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Research Scope and Focus: One of the initial challenges is defining a clear and manageable research scope. Choosing a topic that is too broad can lead to a lack of depth in the dissertation, while a topic that is too narrow may not provide enough material for analysis. Researchers must strike a balance to ensure their research is both feasible and impactful.</li>
<li>Literature Review: Conducting a comprehensive literature review is essential for situating the research within the existing body of knowledge. However, this process can be time-consuming and challenging, as researchers must identify relevant sources, critically evaluate them, and synthesise the information to support their research objectives.</li>
<li>Methodology: Selecting an appropriate research method is critical and requires guidance. Researchers must choose a method that aligns with their research questions and objectives, while also considering practical constraints such as time, resources, and ethical considerations. Decisions about sampling, data collection methods, and data analysis techniques must be carefully considered and justified.</li>
<li>Data management: Collecting and analysing data can present a myriad of difficulties. Researchers must ensure the validity and reliability of their data, which may require careful planning, meticulous attention to detail, and the use of appropriate analytical techniques. Challenges may arise if data collection is hampered by logistical constraints, participant non-response, or data quality issues or loss of data. Ethical requirements as well as data protection laws and regulations need to be considered in every project.</li>
<li>Writing and Presentation: Writing a proposal and dissertation requires strong writing skills and the ability to communicate complex ideas effectively. Researchers must structure their writing logically, maintain a coherent argument throughout the document, and adhere to academic writing conventions. Additionally, formatting requirements and citation styles must be followed meticulously.</li>
</ul>
<p>While this guideline is not meant to address all the potential challenges exhaustively, it serves as a crucial step towards the standardisation of research practices for academic research at KMTC. It provides clear guidelines for formatting proposals and dissertations, thereby aiding students in their academic journey and promoting integrity in scholarly work.</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>8</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-04/PRD/GUD</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="training-for-research">Training for research<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#training-for-research" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>All academic programs will include a module on research. This may be taught at specific departments or as a harmonised course across departments. All students will be required to pass on this module, for the purpose of academic progression. The training will prepare the students to undertake the research projects or case studies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="role-of-the-library">Role of the library<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#role-of-the-library" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The library has a critical role in enhancing knowledge sharing, knowledge translation and other aspects of scholarship. Being an academic library, the KMTC library will serve two three complementary purposes:</p>
<p>i. To support information search, management and evidence synthesis by students and faculty
ii. To support the research activities conducted by students and faculty
iii. To support the training on research in the various academic programs</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="responsibilities-of-the-library">Responsibilities of the library<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-of-the-library" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>i. Serve as a repository for KMTCâ€™s research history, such as storing proposals, dissertations, case studies, publications, guidelines, government gazette notices etc.
ii. Provide access to e-resources, databases, books, etc
iii. Adopt a collection development program and build a special collection for research.
iv. Preserve and organise artefacts and ideas and thereby serving a critical cultural role.
v. Participate in writing research grants
vi. Participate in research training especially on literature search, data searching and evidence synthesis
vii. Participate in research and support collaborations with diverse groups
viii. Research support services such as bibliometric, systematic reviews, data management, digital preservation and curation, open access and open journal publishing.
ix. Support in ensuring academic integrity by conducting plagiarism checks. Students will be required to submit electronic dissertations, projects and case studies to the library before clearance.
x. Advice on bibliographic referencing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="supervision-of-research-projects-and-case-studies">Supervision of research projects and case studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#supervision-of-research-projects-and-case-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Each academic department is responsible for assigning supervisors to students enrolled in diploma or higher diploma courses. It is expected that every student will have at least two supervisors. One of these supervisors will be from KMTC, assigned by the Head of Department, while the other(s) will be from outside the college. Students will be responsible for identifying external supervisors. An external supervisor should be considered on the basis of:</p>
<p>i. Has previously undertaken a research project (professional or academic research)
ii. Has relevant skills or capacity that will be directly applied to the research project e.g. technical expertise, research methods, datasets or statistical analysis.</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-04/PRD/GUD</p>
<p>iii. Willingness to commit time and expertise for supervisory support on a volunteer basis (in keeping with best practices, this is not a paid role).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="requirements-for-supervisors">Requirements for supervisors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#requirements-for-supervisors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Undertake regular training on research ethics. Such training is available on Training and Resources in Research Ethics Evaluation (TRREE) <a href="https://elearning.trree.org/login/index.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://elearning.trree.org/login/index.php</a> and Global Health Training Centre <a href="https://globalhealthtrainingcentre.tghn.org/research-ethics-online-training-v2/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://globalhealthtrainingcentre.tghn.org/research-ethics-online-training-v2/</a>
ii. Participate in knowledge sharing and knowledge translation in your work
iii. Undertake training or mentorship on research, teaching supervision, or leadership.
iv. Have a valid work email for communication with students.
v. Be engaged in research activities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="responsibilities-of-supervisors">Responsibilities of Supervisors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-of-supervisors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Be available for regular consultation with the student and respond to queries raised by students.
ii. Provide feedback on written work submitted by students within two weeks.
iii. Guide students to relevant literature sources.
iv. Critically review students' research ideas, work and presentations
v. Guide students on scholarly writing.
vi. Train students in the conventions of research presentations
vii. Advise students on rules governing research
viii. Conduct plagiarism checks. There are several free online plagiarism checkers e.g. <a href="https://plagiarismdetector.net./" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://plagiarismdetector.net./</a>
ix. Conduct checks on unethical use of artificial intelligence.
x. Keep a track of communication with students as well as individual student progress in research.
xi. Provide written progress reports as required by the department and the college.
xii. Attend viva or other presentations by the student.
xiii. Support the student to publish the work (with the supervisor as a co-author).</p>
<p>In the event of the likelihood of prolonged absence of a supervisor, arrangements must be made by the Head of Department to ensure continuity in supervision. By placing his/her signature on the title page of the dissertation, a supervisor is certifying that the proposal/dissertation represents the work of the candidate that was carried out under his/her supervision and is ready for official examination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="responsibilities-of-the-student">Responsibilities of the student<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-of-the-student" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Undertake training on research ethics and obtain a certificate before undertaking research. Such training is freely available on Training and Resources in Research Ethics Evaluation (TRREE) <a href="https://elearning.trree.org/login/index.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://elearning.trree.org/login/index.php</a> and Global Health Training Centre <a href="https://globalhealthtrainingcentre.tghn.org/research-ethics-online-training-v2/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://globalhealthtrainingcentre.tghn.org/research-ethics-online-training-v2/</a>
ii. Develop the research project or a case study as an original project.</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>3</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-04/PRD/GUD</p>
<p>iii. Identify external research supervisors.
iv. Make initial contact with supervisors and maintain regular consultation with the supervisors.
v. Undertake extensive reading around the topic.
vi. Submit progress reports at the end of every semester through the supervisors.
vii. Participate in research training
viii. Adhere to the college research policies and regulations including guidelines on ethics, anti-plagiarism, and intellectual property rights
ix. Seek the necessary research approvals
x. Adhere to correct format of presenting quotations, footnotes, references, tables, and other illustrative materials
xi. Conduct anti-plagiarism check of own work. There are free online plagiarism checkers e.g. <a href="https://plagiarismdetector.net./" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://plagiarismdetector.net./</a>
xii. Use correct and consistent referencing
xiii. Incorporate corrections recommended by the supervisors
xiv. Secure, organize and present data and evidence professionally and accurately.
xv. Submit the required copies of duly approved proposals and dissertation within timelines
xvi. Ensure that all work submitted is your own original work
xvii. Publish your work, with the help of the supervisor, taking care not to publish in a predatory journal. You should also disseminate your findings to the audience that will apply the findings, including the non-academic audience.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="guidelines-for-supervisory-engagement">Guidelines for supervisory engagement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#guidelines-for-supervisory-engagement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Supervisors should have a first engagement with the students within the first two weeks after supervisors are allocated. Either the student or the supervisor can initiate contact via telephone, email, teleconference or physical meeting. The following should be discussed:
a) Expectations
b) Supervisory arrangements
c) Research topic or question
d) Keeping track of progress
i. A record of the discussions in any meeting and way forward should be kept by both supervisor and student
ii. Shared communication e.g. email to both supervisors on the same email, is encouraged for the purpose of clarity and efficiency
iii. In the event of major conflicts in guidance between supervisors, or between a supervisor and a student, resolution may be sought from the Head of Department or from any other relevant office of the college
iv. Any reports of unethical conduct from either party should be reported to the Head of Department or other office of the college as soon as possible
v. Continuity is important. Supervisors who expect to be away for prolonged periods should make arrangements for continuity of supervision</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>KMTC/QP-04/PRD/GUD</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="choice-of-research-topic">Choice of research topic<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#choice-of-research-topic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A good research topic should be:</p>
<p>i. Relevant to the area of specialty or study or practice of the student
ii. Researchable, using the expertise, time and resources available
iii. Of interest to the field
iv. Addressing a specific gap in knowledge or practice
v. Chosen after extensive reading around the published literature</p>
<p>The student is responsible for choosing a topic with the help of the supervisors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="format-for-research-proposals">FORMAT FOR RESEARCH PROPOSALS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#format-for-research-proposals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cover-page">Cover page<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cover-page" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Items on this page should be arranged in the following order:</p>
<p>i. Begin with the title of the study.
ii. Title should be focused, informative and between 15 to 20 words.
iii. Full name of student.
iv. Registration number of the student below the name.
v. Name of department.</p>
<p>Then follows the writing:</p>
<p>"A research proposal submitted to Kenya Medical Training College in partial fulfilment of the requirements for the award of diploma (specify, e.g. Clinical Medicine)."</p>
<p>Insert date of submission e.g. July 2024</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="note">Note:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cover page should not be paginated.</p>
<p>All wording should be singled spaced.</p>
<p>KMTC logo should <strong>not</strong> be inserted on the cover page or in any part of the protocol or dissertation or case study.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="declaration">DECLARATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#declaration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Should be on a fresh page with the title â€œDeclarationâ€. This page should have the following writings.</p>
<p>"This proposal is my original work and has not been presented for a diploma in any other institution."</p>
<p>Then the student signs above his/her name and college registration number, followed by the date.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>

<p>KMTC/QP-04/PRD/GUD</p>
<p>Signature ... Date ...
Name Richard, Baraka
DEHS/17001/2018</p>
<p>Supervisors:</p>
<p>This proposal has been submitted for review with our approval as supervisors.</p>
<p>Then the supervisors, each, starting with the lead, sign above at least two of their names written in full, together with their respective departments.</p>

<p>Signature

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intellectual-property-rights">Intellectual Property Rights<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intellectual-property-rights" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Students retain full copyright to the research outputs.</p>
<p>Below the declaration and supervisors, insert the copyright statement.</p>
<p>â˜‘ Copyright, Year. Full name of student as it appears on the document. All rights reserved.</p>
<p>E.g.</p>
<p>â˜‘ Copyright, 2024. Rose Mwende Mutisya. All rights reserved.</p>
