<li>Religion e.g. Christian, Islam, Hinduism, ATR e.g. variable marital status may be included in a research. The researcher then can operationalise this variable as married, single, divorced, separated
The researcher would then number the subjects that fall in (3) separated (4) these numbers are for identification e.g. married (40) single (10) divorced(5) separated(1) in a frequency.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‰»</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\succ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">â‰»</span></span></span></span></span> Numbers are often assigned to various categories for the purpose of identification. We could have assigned 1-married, 2- single, 3-divorced, 4- separated
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‰»</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\succ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">â‰»</span></span></span></span></span> These numbers do not represent quantities or order, addition, subtraction, division, multiplication of this numbers would yield meaningless values.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‰»</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\succ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">â‰»</span></span></span></span></span> Variables that can take two categories are referred to as "Dichotomous" e.g. sex can take either male and female</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-1-2-ordinal-scale">5.4.1.2 Ordinal scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-2-ordinal-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‰»</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\succ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">â‰»</span></span></span></span></span> The scale groups subjects into categories and also ranks them into same order either ascending, descending (highest to lowest) or (lowest to highest)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‰»</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\succ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">â‰»</span></span></span></span></span> Numerical represent relative position or order among the values of the variables
E.g. nursing cadres (KECN, KRN, KRCHN, BSN, MSN, PHD)
Social economic class (low, mild, upper class)</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Severity of anaemia (mild, moderate, severe)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-1-3-interval-scale">5.4.1.3 Interval scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-3-interval-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In this class, numbers assigned in each measure are ranked in order and interval between numbers are equal</li>
<li>Numerical used represent quantities in mathematical operations (+ve, -ve) on numerical would yield meaningful values but this mathematical operations are limited to addition and subtraction (multiplication and divisions are not applicable)</li>
<li>In this scale, there's no true 0 point i.e. It can take-ve values e.g. interval scale measures include;</li>
<li>Temp. in test score or in foren height e.g. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>99</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mo>âˆ’</mo><msup><mn>98</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mo>âˆ’</mo><msup><mn>98.2</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">99^{\circ}\mathrm{c} - 98^{\circ}\mathrm{c} - 98.2^{\circ}\mathrm{c}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7574em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">9</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">c</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7574em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">c</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">98.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">c</span></span></span></span></span> order and interval of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>0.4</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">âˆ˜</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.4^{\circ}\mathrm{c}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">0.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">âˆ˜</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">c</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-1-4-ratio-scale">5.4.1.4 Ratio scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-4-ratio-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is the highest level of measurement, it's the most precise method of measuring a variable</li>
<li>It has all characteristics of other scales (nominal, internal, ordinal)</li>
<li>It has a true 0 point and all mathematical operations can be applied to yield meaningful values</li>
<li>Most physical objects can be measured at the ratio scale e.g. Weight, height, age, area, BP, distance e.t.c. e.g. a field <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1000\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> long is as twice as long as one which is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> long. Therefore <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> long means no length as weight</li>
</ul>
<p>NB</p>
<p>Page 61</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>&gt; When considering interval and ratio scale, there are 2 types of variables</p>
<p>i. <strong>Discrete variable</strong>: these can take only exact numbers (whole numbers)
ii. <strong>Continuous variable</strong>: these measures can theoretically occur at any point in a continuous e.g. Height 5.2m, 5.65m, age 24.3years 34.8months</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-instruments-in-research">5.5 INSTRUMENTS IN RESEARCH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-instruments-in-research" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; An ideal instrument is one which results in measurements that are relevant, accurate, objective, sensitive and efficient
&gt; An instrument is a device used to measure the concept of interest in a research project
&gt; Instruments can be;
&gt; i. Observation scales, forms or checklist
&gt; ii. Questionnaires
&gt; iii. Interview schedules
&gt; iv. Standardized tests</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-questionnaires">5.5.1 QUESTIONNAIRES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-questionnaires" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Itâ€™s the commonly used tool
&gt; Each item in the questionnaire is used to address a specific objective research question or hypothesis of the study
&gt; The researcher must know how each item in the questionnaire is to be analyzed
&gt; A questionnaire must be well thought or it will;
&gt;   Cause a confusion to the respondent on the information required
&gt;   Discourage the respondents to an extent of discarding it
&gt;   It may leave important information</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-1-categories-of-questions-used-in-a-questionnaire">5.5.1.1 CATEGORIES OF QUESTIONS USED IN A QUESTIONNAIRE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-1-categories-of-questions-used-in-a-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) <strong>Structural or close ended</strong></p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>These are accompanied with possible alternatives from where respondents selects the answer that will best describe the situation</li>
<li>Always has the other(specify) option to cater for any category that might have been left out eg. What do you crave for in pregnancy apart from food?</li>
<li>clay - charcoal - others (specify)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages-of-structured-questions">Disadvantages of structured questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages-of-structured-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>They are more difficult to construct because categories must be well thought out</li>
<li>Responses are limited and the respondent is compelled to answer according to research choices</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-structured-questions">Advantages of structured questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-structured-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Are easy to analyze</li>
<li>Easy to administer because each items followed by alternative answers</li>
<li>Are economical in time and costs</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-unstructured-open-question">b) Unstructured / open question<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-unstructured-open-question" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>They give the respondent freedom of response</li>
<li>They have no present alternatives</li>
</ul>
<p>E.g. how do you handle cases of malpractice?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-open-ended-questions">Advantages of open ended questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-open-ended-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. They yield in depth responses
ii. They are simpler to formulate because the researcher does not need to labour to come up with appropriate categories
iii. Responses give insight to the feelings, attitudes, interest, decisions, hidden motivations and background
iv. They stimulate persons to think about his feelings or motives and to express what he considers to be most important</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages">Disadvantages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Answers given might be irrelevant to the research objectives</p>
<p>Page 63</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>ii. They are hard to categorize and analyze
iii. They are time consuming for respondents and may put them off.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-contingency-questions">c) Contingency questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-contingency-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Are applicable to certain respondents only and not all</li>
<li>These are follow up questions and are required to get further information from relevant subgroup also called 'filter' questions</li>
<li>They are used to probe for more information and save the respondent from answering questions which are irrelevant to them</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Have you ever been pricked by a needle?</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Yes...</li>
<li>No...</li>
<li>If yes how many times</li>
<li>Once...</li>
<li>2-4 times...</li>
<li>Over 4 times...</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Have you ever used any contraceptives</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Yes...</li>
<li>No...</li>
<li>The questions can be structured or unstructured</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-matrix-questions">c) Matrix questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-matrix-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>These are questions that share same set of response categories</li>
<li>Are common whenever scales are used</li>
<li>Examples how are you satisfied with you job?</li>
<li>a) Financial 12345</li>
<li>b) Quality of life 12345</li>
<li>c) Level of assets 12345</li>
<li>d) Ability to save 12345</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key">Key<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>1- Extremely dissatisfied</li>
<li>2- Dissatisfied</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>3- Neutral
4- Satisfied
5- Extremely satisfied</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-matrix-questions">Advantages of matrix questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-matrix-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) They are easy to complete and unlikely to put off respondents
b) Space is used efficiently
c) It is easy to compare responses given to different items. The researcher can easily detect a trend just by glancing at the responses
d) They are easy to analyze</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages-of-matrix-questions">Disadvantages of matrix questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages-of-matrix-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Because they are easy to construct and analyze they can be misused
b) Some respondents may form a pattern of agreeing or disagreeing with all items</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-2-rules-for-constructing-a-questionnaire-and-its-items">5.5.1.2 RULES FOR CONSTRUCTING A QUESTIONNAIRE AND ITS ITEMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-2-rules-for-constructing-a-questionnaire-and-its-items" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Start by listing the specific objectives that you want the questionnaire to accomplish</li>
<li>Determine how each item is to be analyzed</li>
<li>Ensure clarity avoid terms like â€˜mostâ€™ or several</li>
<li>If a concept has several meanings, then the intended meaning must be defined</li>
<li>Short questions are preferred to long ones</li>
<li>Items should be stated positively as much as possible. Negative words are easily overlooked by respondents</li>
<li>Questions with two separate items should be avoided</li>
<li>Leading or biased questions should be avoided</li>
<li>Very personal and sensitive questions should be avoided</li>
<li>Use simple words that are easy to understand</li>
<li>Avoid psychologically threatening questions eg. Are you worried of the consequences of divorce?</li>
<li>Avoid questions that assume facts without evidence</li>
<li>Make complete meaningful statements</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-3-pretesting-a-questionnaire">5.5.1.3 PRETESTING A QUESTIONNAIRE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-3-pretesting-a-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>6 This is trying out the questionnaire in the field</p>
<p>This document is available on
5
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>7 It should be tried to sample which is similar to the actual selected sample. Subject in the actual sample should not be used in the pretest
8 The pretest sample should be 1%-10% of the sample size</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reasons-for-pretest">Reasons for pretest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reasons-for-pretest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Vague questions will be revealed as the respondents will interpret them differently
ii. Other deficiencies will be revealed e.g. unclear instructions, limited space, wrong numbering
iii. Comments and suggestions from the respondents during pretest will improve the questionnaire if incorporated
iv. Because few questions are analyzed, the method of analysis appropriateness is tested</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-4-ways-of-administering-a-questionnaire">5.5.1.4 WAYS OF ADMINISTERING A QUESTIONNAIRE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-4-ways-of-administering-a-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-self-administered-questionnaire">a) Self administered questionnaire<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-self-administered-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Respondents fill questionnaires themselves which can be sent to them by mail or by hand delivery</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-researcher-administered-by-questionnaire">b) Researcher administered by questionnaire<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-researcher-administered-by-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcher interviews the respondents using a questionnaire</li>
<li>This is applicable when the respondents may not have the ability to interpret the questions because of their educational levels</li>
<li>Questions are read out to the respondents and their options/choices are written down</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-using-internet">c) Using internet<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-using-internet" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sampling and collection of data is done through the internet and responses are given via e-mail or website.</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 67</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-5-2-interview-schedule">5.5.2 INTERVIEW SCHEDULE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-2-interview-schedule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a set of questions that the interview asks when interviewing</li>
<li>It is used to orally obtain data from the respondent</li>
<li>Cooperation is key to good results. Good rapport is a must</li>
<li>Questions in the interview schedule can be structured or unstructured</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-interview">Advantages of Interview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. In depth data is obtained which cannot be obtained with questionnaires
ii. It is precise in attaining specific objectives
iii. There is no confusion as the interviewer can clarify the questions
iv. It is more flexible than questionnaires
v. Can capture very sensitive and personal information by honest and personal interaction between the researcher and respondents
vi. You can get more information by probing
vii. Can also expose negative responses through interaction and genuine conversation
viii. There is high response rate because it is not easy to refuse to answer questions or completely ignore the researcher.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages">Disadvantages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Interview are expensive as time, travelling to meet respondents is costly.
ii. It calls for high level communication and interpersonal skills. Which some researcher may lack
iii. There could be interviews bias hence need training to avoid bias
iv. The interview may be subjective in that the subjects may be too eager to please the researcher. Again the researcher may ask questions to support his perceived notions
v. Because it is time consuming, the researcher may be forced to use a small sample
vi. Respondents may have bias/prejudice. E.g. affluent researcher going to a poor community may influence the respondent's reaction</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>S  studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 68</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-5-2-1-data-collection-during-interview">5.5.2.1 DATA COLLECTION DURING INTERVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-2-1-data-collection-during-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Data can be collected by;</p>
<p>i. Note taking- where the researcher takes notes as the subjects answer questions asked. Should be done carefully not to upset the respondent. Responses should be recorded the way they are expressed
ii. Tape recording- responses are recorded in a video or a tape recorder. One should be careful when recording.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-5-3-standadized-tests">5.5.3 STANDADIZED TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-3-standadized-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A standardized test is one that has consistency and uniform procedures for administering scoring and interpreting the behavior of the subjects. E.g. 1Q intelligence tests</li>
<li>Graduate record examination (GRE) usually by students wishing to pursue further studies abroad</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-5-4-observation-forms-schedules-or-checklists">5.5.4 OBSERVATION FORMS SCHEDULES OR CHECKLISTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-4-observation-forms-schedules-or-checklists" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These are used to record what the researcher observes during data collection</li>
<li>The behaviours to be observed must be defined. The observer checks off each observed behavior as they occur</li>
<li>Sometimes rating scales are used, responses are recorded and evaluated</li>
<li>Can be used by;</li>
<li>Non participant observer or</li>
<li>Participant observer</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-6-reliability-and-validity-in-research">5.6 RELIABILITY AND VALIDITY IN RESEARCH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-reliability-and-validity-in-research" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Data techniques must yield information that is relevant and correct.</li>
<li>Reliability and validity are measures of this correctness and relevance</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-6-1-reliability">5.6.1 RELIABILITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-1-reliability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>This is the degree to which a research instrument yields consistent results or data after repeated trials</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Reliability is influenced by random error in deviation from true measurement due to factors that have not effectively been addressed by the researcher</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>As random error increases, reliability decreases. Random error may arise from:-</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inaccurate coding</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ambiguous instructions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Interviewers fatigue</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Interviewees fatigue</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Interviewers bias</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Random errors will always exist regardless of the design. Example of error:-</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In a study done on the effect of drug A on blood pressure; If the BP machine used underestimates or overestimates the readings, this will lead to unreliable result</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are 3 types of random errors:-</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>i. Error due to instrument inaccuracy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ii. Error due to inaccuracy of scoring by researcher</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>iii. Unexplained errors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The research process is aimed at reducing the random error and increase reliability</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are four ways of assessing reliability of data each dealing with different aspect of the concept</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-1-1-test-retest-technique">5.6.1.1 TEST-RETEST TECHNIQUE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-1-1-test-retest-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This technique involves administering the same instrument twice to the same group of subjects with a time lapse between (1-4 weeks)</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on
Studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 70</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="steps">Steps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>i. Select an appropriate group of subjects
ii. Administer the test to the subjects
iii. Keep all conditions constant, administer the same test to the subjects
iv. Correlate the scores from both testing periods</p>
<p>Disadvantages of this technique includes subjects sensitization as subjects may tend to remember their previous response and also difficulties in establishing a reasonable period between the two test sessions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-1-2-the-equivalent-form-technique">5.6.1.2 THE EQUIVALENT FORM TECHNIQUE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-1-2-the-equivalent-form-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This uses two equivalent instruments</li>
<li>Specific items in each form are different but are designed to measure the same concept</li>
<li>The items are the same in number, structure and level of difficulty</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Using one scale to measure the weight of subjects today and after a week using different scale to measure weight of the same subject</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">Steps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Sample different items from the domain indicators that measure the variable
ii. Divide the items thus sampled into two groups or form
iii. Administer one form to a group of subjects randomly selected
iv. After a period of time administer the other form of instrument to the same group keeping all the conditions constant
v. Correlate the scores obtained from the two forms of instruments.</p>
<ul>
<li>Is commonly used in establishing the reliability of standardized test data e.g. Intelligence tests, achievement tests, TOEFL, etc</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-1-3-split-half-technique">5.6.1.3 SPLIT-HALF TECHNIQUE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-1-3-split-half-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This requires only one testing session. An instrument is designed with two parts.</p>
<ul>
<li>Subject's scores from one part are correlated with scores from the second part.</li>
<li>Major advantage with this technique is that it eliminates advance error</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">Steps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Sample items from domain indicators that measure the variable
ii. Administer the total test to an appropriate group
iii. At random, divide the scored items into two groups e.g. Odd number items together and even numbers together
iv. Compute each subject's total score from the two groups of items
v. Correlate the scores from the 2 groups of items for all subjects</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-1-4-internal-consistency-technique">5.6.1.4 INTERNAL CONSISTENCY TECHNIQUE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-1-4-internal-consistency-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is determined from scores obtained from a single test administered by the researcher to a sample of the subjects</li>
<li>Scores obtained in one item is correlated with scores obtained from other items in the tool</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-2-validity">5.6.2 VALIDITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-2-validity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Validity is the accuracy and meaningfulness of inferences, which are based on the research findings</li>
</ul>
<p>Or</p>
<ul>
<li>It is the degree to which results obtained from the analysis of the data actually represent the phenomena understudy</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>&gt; Validity is largely determined by the presence or absence of systematic/non-random error. This is an error that has a consistent boosting effect on the measuring instrument</p>
<p>E.g. A faculty weighing scale overestimating subject weight.</p>
<p>&gt; This error is non-random because the obtained readings are either always above or below the true score i.e. always in one direction</p>
<p>&gt; There are 3 types of validity in data</p>
<p><strong>i. Construct validity</strong></p>
<p>This is the measure of the degree to which data obtained from an instrument meaningfully and accurately represents or reflects a theoretical concept.</p>
<p><strong>Example</strong></p>
<p>Does a score of 90 points on a reading test actually reflect the true reading ability of a pupil or would score in biology, chem., phyc, and language reflect ones attitude of being a good doctor or nurse</p>
<p>This approach is often used where no criteria or domain of content is generally accepted as an adequate measure of a concept. Concepts management, intelligence, motivation etc. are all abstract, hypothetical concepts. They cannot be directly observed but their effects on the behavior of subjects can be observed</p>
<p>To measure construct validity, there must be a theoretical framework regarding the concept to be measured</p>
<p>The measurements are consistent with theoretical expectations</p>
<p>If the measurements are consistent with theoretical expectations, then the data have construct validity and vice versa</p>
<p><strong>To assess construct validity;</strong></p>
<p>Use two different instruments which measure the same concept</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Compute the validity coefficient</p>
<p>I.e. data is obtained simultaneously from the same sample</p>
<p>ii. <strong>Content validity</strong></p>
<p>This is a measure of the degree to which data collected using a particular instrument represents a specific domain of indicators or content of a particular concept or it can be defined as the measure of the degree/extent to which a measure represents all facets of a given construct</p>
<p><strong>Example</strong></p>
<p>A test of arithmetic for standard 4 pupils would not yield content valid data if items do not include all four operations: multiplication, addition, subtraction and division</p>
<p>The usual procedure in assessing the content validity of a measure is to ask experts in the particular field</p>
<p>iii. <strong>Criterion -related validity</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>This refers to the use of a measure in assessing subjects behavior in specific situations. If an instrument purports to measure performance in a job, the subjects who score high in the instrument must also perform well in their jobs</li>
<li>There are two types of criterion related validity</li>
</ul>
<p>a) <strong>Predictive validity</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Refers to the degree to which obtained data predict future behavior of subjects</li>
<li>Job interviews should have high predictive validity to determine the future performance of the candidate</li>
</ul>
<p>b) <strong>Concurrent validity</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>This refers to the degree to which data are able to predict behavior of subjects in the present but not in the future</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Example:</strong></p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>A surgeon might use a measure to determine whether a patient with acute abdomen is fit for surgery or not</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-3-internal-and-external-validity">5.6.3 INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL VALIDITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-3-internal-and-external-validity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Def.</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>internal validity is the degree to which extraneous variables are controlled in a study</li>
</ul>
<p>If extraneous variables have not been controlled for we will not know the observed effects on the dependent variable due to the independent variable or to extraneous variables</p>
<p>When extraneous variables are controlled for, the effects can accurately be attributed to independent variable. Therefore such research study is said to have high internal validity.</p>
<p>Randomization is an important component of the internal validity of a study</p>
<p><strong>External validity</strong> refers to the degree to which research findings can be generalized to populations and environment outside the experimental settings</p>
<p>If research findings are only applicable to the sample, the study findings are not externally valid and hence not generalizable to other populations</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-3-1-threats-to-internal-validity">5.6.3.1 Threats to internal validity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-3-1-threats-to-internal-validity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>1. History</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Some researches especially physical and biological extend over a period of time. During this extended period, events occur which have influence on the subject such that results may partly be due to extraneous factors such factors influence research findings and hence internal validity is reduced</li>
<li>Occurrence of events that influence experimental units during the course of the study is called history</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Example</strong></p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>A researcher may want to determine the difference between two methods of therapy given to patients suffering anxiety, the research is to extend for 3 months. During this period its possible some patients may be involved in activities such as group support, hobbies, psychology classes, which keep reduce anxiety. Therefore it will be difficult to determine the true difference in these methods of therapy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-maturation">2. Maturation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-maturation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This refers to biological or psychological process which occur among subjects in a relatively short time and which influence research findings. This can be more intellectually enlightened, motivated, fatigued, irritable or discouraged</li>
<li>Maturation can be controlled by application of appropriate research designs</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-instrumentation">3. Instrumentation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-instrumentation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This occurs when the measuring instrument is unreliable</li>
<li>It can also occur when research assistants are not consistent among themselves in observing, scoring or assessing the characteristics under study</li>
</ul>
<p>To avoid this, the researcher should develop accurate tools and standardize data collection by holding a training session for all before data collection</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-pretesting">4. Pretesting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-pretesting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In a pretest and post test experimental research, pretest sensitizes the subjects and therefore they tend to perform better in post test. The better performance in post test is not due to the treatment alone, but the pretest sensitized them</li>
<li>A reliable method to avoid this problem is to use equivalent form tests</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-statistical-regression">5. Statistical regression<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-statistical-regression" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a problem where the selection of subjects is based on their performance in the pretest for example giving a pretest to students and selecting the top scores to take in a study. On completion they are</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>given a post test. In this scenario, it is likely that their mean score of post test will be lower than the pretest mean score. If you selected the lower scores and did the same as top scores, the mean score on post-test for them will be higher than their mean score in the pretest</p>
<ul>
<li>The explanation in the above situation is that extreme scores tend to have the highest errors of measurements.</li>
<li>On retesting, external scores tend to regress towards the mean score</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-attrition">6. Attrition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-attrition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Attrition or experimental mortality refers to the situation where many subjects drop out of the study before the study is completed.</li>
<li>It may occur that only subjects with common characteristics are left in the study. E.g. Less motivated and lower performers drop out and leave well motivated and higher performers. This has some effect as biased sampling.</li>
<li>Attrition interferes with original randomness of the sample and this leads to errors.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-differential-selection">7. Differential selection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-differential-selection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This occurs when subjects are systematically selected into a treatment group. This selection interferes with randomness of the sample. For example, if subjects are selected for a study because they volunteered, comparing such a group to a control group of non-volunteers introduces bias and error in the results. Volunteers are more motivated and are more interested unlike non-volunteers.</li>
<li>Differential selection is a factor when a researcher uses a whole, in fact group as a sample</li>
<li>Commonly occurs in studies such as case study or where multi-stage sampling technique has been used.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-6-3-2-threats-to-external-validity">5.6.3.2 THREATS TO EXTERNAL VALIDITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-3-2-threats-to-external-validity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Various factors pose a threat to external validity or generalization of research findings</p>
<p>These include:</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>i. Accessible and target population</p>
<p>&gt; Subjects are sampled from the accessible population. If the sample, accessible and target population are similar on salient characteristics, then generalization will be made. If accessible and target population are not similar in salient characteristics, then generalization of the research findings are only limited to the accessible population.</p>
<p>&gt; This occurs when random sampling is not applied and hence, inference to any population is not possible.</p>
<p>ii. Control of extraneous variables</p>
<p>&gt; Research controls the subjects of extraneous variables by including them in the study. E.g. if gender is a possible extraneous variable in a study, one may consider only one level of the variable (male or female only). Strong control may increase the internal validity of a study but it may, at the same time reduce the generalizability of the results because such control may mean taking a smaller sample. A balance is needed between internal and external validity.</p>
<p>iii. Pre-test treatment interaction</p>
<p>&gt; In a pre-test and pilot-test study, subjects may score higher on the post-test due to the treatment given and pre-test sensitization.</p>
<p>&gt; Pre-test treatment interaction makes the results only applicable or generalizable to the target population</p>
<p>iv. Explicit description of the variables</p>
<p>&gt; Study variables must specifically be defining both conceptually and operationally.</p>
<p>&gt; To increase the degree to which results are generalizable to other population, a researcher must operationalize the variables in such a way that the measures have a meaning outside the setting of the particular study.</p>
<p>&gt; Generalization of the research findings is made on the assumption that there exists a universal language and a universal way of measuring a particular variable.</p>
<p>Page 77</p>
<p>This document is available on 5 studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>v. Non-randomness of the sample</p>
<p>&gt; Results from studies, which are done with non-random groups can only be generalized to those groups because of the unrepresentativeness of the sample used. Randomness increases representation</p>
<p>vi. Multi-treatment inference</p>
<p>&gt; Occurs when two treatments are applied to the same group but at different times. One drug may have a long duration and therefore its effect may interfere with effect of the other. In such situation it's difficult to determine the difference(true difference) between the treatments
&gt; The solution to this problem is to lengthen the duration between the treatments. Alternatively randomly assigns subjects to two sub-groups and administer the different treatment to the subgroups.</p>
<p>5.7 COMMON EFFECTS TO THE RESEARCH PROCESS</p>
<ul>
<li>These threatens both internal and external validities simultaneously</li>
<li>These have nothing to do with the treatment</li>
<li>These include;</li>
</ul>
<p>5.7.1 The Hawthorne-effect</p>
<ul>
<li>This refers to a situation where subjects awareness of being in an experiment group motivates them to perform better.</li>
<li>There must be influential factor is not independent variable but the awareness is being in the special groups</li>
<li>Hawthorne effect is particularly in observational studies</li>
<li>One of the solutions is possible use hidden cameras to observe the behavior of subjects during the study or the researcher can become a participant in whatever the subject are to do.</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 78</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>5.7.2 Placebo effect</p>
<ul>
<li>Generally common in medical research. Drugs administered have a chemical effect and psychological effect</li>
<li>A placebo is a chemically inactive substance which tastes and has colour of the drug in question</li>
<li>Some subjects even when given a placebo report improvement effect.</li>
<li>This results not from the drug but psychological effect</li>
</ul>
<p>5.7.3 The John Henry effect</p>
<ul>
<li>This refers to situations where control group perform much higher than its usual average simply because they are placed in competitive position with experimental group. E.g. manual tea pickers competing with picking with machines</li>
</ul>
<p>5.7.4 The Pygmalion effect</p>
<ul>
<li>This refers to situations where subjects perform much better because of researcherâ€™s expectations</li>
<li>Researchers may act or behave in away suggestive of his/her expectations to the subjects. The subjects in an attempt to please the researcher may work much harder than usual and give responses which meet the researchers expectations</li>
<li>This may be during the time of instructions</li>
<li>To deal with this, the researcher should give minimal instructions</li>
</ul>
<p>5.7.5 The Halo effect</p>
<p>Page 79</p>
<p>This document is available on studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>This is common in observational researcher</li>
<li>It is rating subjects on some variable</li>
<li>Halo effect refers to a situation where the researcher rating are influenced by his/her initial impression of the subject or research is influenced by the subjects' previous performance on another variable.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-conducting-a-pretest-pilot-study">5.8 CONDUCTING A PRETEST/PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-conducting-a-pretest-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Before you carry out the full scale data collection process, it is important to conduct a trial to see whether the instruments planned for collecting data are actually appropriate for the study and whether are collecting the information you need.</p>
<ul>
<li>To achieve this, you have to carry out a pilot study/pretest</li>
<li>Pretest or pilot study is defined as;</li>
<li>A small version of a proposed study conducted to refine the methodology or</li>
<li>Is the process of carrying out preliminary study going through the entire research procedure with a small sample. Or</li>
<li>Pretest refers to a small scale trial of a particular research component</li>
<li>In a pilot study, respondents chosen have characteristics to those to be used during the actual research</li>
<li>The settings should be almost similar</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-1-purposes-of-a-pre-test-pilot-study">5.8.1 PURPOSES OF A PRE-TEST/PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-1-purposes-of-a-pre-test-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A pilot study is done to;</p>
<p>i. To ensure that items in the data collection instruments are stated clearly and have the same meaning to all research respondents (Refine where necessary)
ii. To determine whether the proposed study is feasible
iii. To identify any problems with the research design
iv. To assess the time taken to administer the research instruments</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>v. To determine whether the sample is representative of the population
vi. To determine the effectiveness of the sampling technique used
vii. To give the researcher the real experience in the field (with the respondents, environment, methodology and instruments)
viii. Determine the human and financial resources requirement for the study
ix. Determine the effectiveness of the training given to research assistants where necessary
x. Evaluate the procedure for data process and analysis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-2-appropriate-time-to-conduct-a-pilot-study">5.8.2 APPROPRIATE TIME TO CONDUCT A PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-2-appropriate-time-to-conduct-a-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It should be conducted before the actual full-scale study.</li>
<li>The advantages of conducting the pre-test before finalizing the proposal is that one can draft the work plan and budget based on realistic estimates</li>
<li>Also one can revise the data collection tools he/she submits the proposal for approval</li>
<li>Can be done before or after training research assistants or immediately after</li>
<li>If it is not possible to do it in the above circumstances, e.g. the proposal being drafted far from the field or no similar research settings available close to the drafting site, the pretest can be done after finishing the proposal. However it should be done long before the actual field work to allow for a thorough revision of data collection tools.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-3-using-findings-of-the-pre-test-pilot-study">5.8.3 USING FINDINGS OF THE PRE-TEST/PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-3-using-findings-of-the-pre-test-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Identify any sensitive or annoying items in the instrument and rectify them</li>
<li>Any question that interviewers had to repeat and explain several times to respondents need to be rectified</li>
<li>Analyze the results of this pre-test and develop dummy tables</li>
</ul>
