<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-9-data-collection">5.9 DATA COLLECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-9-data-collection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This document is available on
5
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>This is one of the major steps of the research process
This is what determines the findings of the research study
As discussed earlier, there are several tools that can be used in data collection. The common ones are;</p>
<ul>
<li>Questionnaires</li>
<li>Interview schedules</li>
<li>Observation charts/checklists</li>
<li>Standardized texts etc.</li>
</ul>
<p>The various methods of data collection which are closely linked with the tools include, interviewing respondents, observing either as a participant or non-participant, focused group discussions and questionnaires
Interviews can be face-to-face or telephone interviews
Reviewing existing records can also be used to collect data
Data collection is defined as â€˜the precise systematic gathering of information relevant to the research purpose or specific objectives, questions or hypotheses of a study</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-9-1-data-collection-plan">5.9.1 DATA COLLECTION PLAN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-9-1-data-collection-plan" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A plan for data collection can be made using the following steps</p>
<ul>
<li>List tasks that have to be carried out and who should be involved.</li>
<li>Make a rough estimate of the time needed for different parts of the study</li>
<li>Identify the most appropriate period to carry out the research</li>
<li>Schedule the different activities that have to be carried out each week in a work plan</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-9-1-1-a-data-collection-plan-serves-various-purposes">5.9.1.1 A data collection plan serves various purposes;<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-9-1-1-a-data-collection-plan-serves-various-purposes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>i. One will have a clear overview of what tasks to be carried out, who should perform and duration of these tasks
ii. You can organize both human and material resources for data collection in the most efficient way and minimize errors
iii. You will identify problems that will require modifications to the proposal</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-9-2-stages-of-data-collection">5.9.2 Stages of data collection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-9-2-stages-of-data-collection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are 3 stages</p>
<p>i. Permission to proceed
ii. Data collection
iii. Data handling</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stage-1-permission-to-proceed">Stage 1: Permission to proceed<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-1-permission-to-proceed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Consent must be obtained from relevant authorities, individuals and the community in which the project is to be carried out</p>
<p>It may involve organizing meetings at national, provincial or provincial level, district and at large</p>
<p>Informed consent needs to be obtained especially in clinical studies</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stage-2-data-collection">Stage 2: Data collection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-2-data-collection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this stage logistics for the research study is considered</p>
<p>This entails who will collect what, when to collect, with what resources and quality control</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="who-will-collect-what-data">Who will collect what data?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#who-will-collect-what-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To allocate tasks, first list the tasks to be done and then identify who could best implement each of the tasks</p>
<p>This document is available on
5
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Research assistants may be needed to assist in data collection. They need training and compensation Tasks needs to be clearly allocated</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-long-does-it-take-to-collect-data">How long does it take to collect data?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-long-does-it-take-to-collect-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The following should be considered in determining the duration of data collection;</p>
<p>i. The time required to reach to the study area(s)
ii. The time needed to walk around and build rapport in the community
iii. The time needed to locate the study units (persons, groups)
iv. The number of visits per study unit-in some studies it may be necessary to visit informant a number of times
v. The time required for quality control of the collected data to judge their validity
vi. The time required for preliminary analysis of the data</p>
<p>&gt; Having considered the mentioned points above, data collection plan can be drawn up as follows;</p>
<ul>
<li>Calculate the number of interviews to be carried per day e.g.</li>
<li>Calculate the number of days needed to carry out the interviews e.g. 200 interviews and research team of 5. 5 people x4 interviews per day =2 interviews per day No. of days=200/20=10 days for the interviews</li>
<li>Calculate the time needed for other methods e.g. 5 days for familiarization and rapport 5 days for focused group discussions, 3 days for participant observation and so on.</li>
<li>Determine how much time the research team can devote to field work</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; If the time required according to the calculation is more than time available it may be necessary to recruit research assistants for certain components of the study e.g. conducting interviews. Local health workers, local staff from related services (e.g. teachers) students and village community health workers...etc.</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 85</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sequence-of-data-collection">Sequence of Data collection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sequence-of-data-collection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Starts with already available data. Focus discussion groups which are devised to focus the content of questionnaires, should be carried at before the finalization of the questionnaire.</li>
<li>If focus group discussions are to provide feedback on issues raised, in larger survey, they should be conducted after preliminary analysis of the questionnaire.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="when-data-should-be-collected">When data should be collected<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#when-data-should-be-collected" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The type of data and the demands of the project will determine the actual period of data collection. One should consider:</p>
<p>i. The availability of the research team members and assistants
ii. The appropriate season(s) to conduct field work (if the problem and season related)
iii. The accessibility and availability of the sample population
iv. Public holidays and weekends/vacation periods</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ensuring-quality">Ensuring Quality<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ensuring-quality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Data collected should be reliable and valid otherwise we may come out with false or misleading conclusions</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>To ensure data quality, prepare a field work manual for the research team as a whole. This should include:</li>
</ol>
<p>Guidelines on sampling procedures and what to do if respondents are not available or refuse to cooperate</p>
<p>A clear explanation of the purpose and procedures of the study which should be used to introduce each interview</p>
<p>Instruction sheet on how to ask certain questions and how to record the answers</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Ensure you select assistants with care. Choose those who are:</li>
</ol>
<p>From same educational level</p>
<p>Knowledgeable concerning the topic and local conditions</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s  t  u  d  o  c  u</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Not biased concerning the topic</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Ensure pretest of research instruments and research procedures with the whole research team, including research assistants. Do not put research assistants under too much pressure</li>
<li>Have an ongoing supervision of research assistants</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stage-3-data-handling">Stage 3: Data Handling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-3-data-handling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This includes the procedure for handling and storing data</p>
<p>Use these guidelines;</p>
<p>a) Check that all data gathered are complete and accurate
b) Questionnaires will need numbering
c) Identify the person responsible for storing and where to store
d) Decide how data should be stored</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-9-3-data-entry">5.9.3 Data entry<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-9-3-data-entry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Data entry is keying the data into cards or disks so that analytic software can process them. This starts by:</p>
<p>Deciding the format i.e. how you will organize data in a file</p>
<ul>
<li>Design a code i.e. the rules by which the respondents answers will be assigned values that can be processed by the computer</li>
<li>Actual coding i.e. responses are turned into standardized categories you developed</li>
<li>Data cleaning i.e. final check you make on the data for accuracy, completeness and consistency prior to the onset of analysis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-0-writing-a-research-proposal">6.0 WRITING A RESEARCH PROPOSAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-0-writing-a-research-proposal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Proposal - Is a document which details an intended activity e.g. a research or project</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Once a proposal has been accepted by an institution, or a funding agency, the writer of the proposal is obliged to follow the steps outlined in the proposal.
A proposal demonstrates the researcherâ€™s ability to think clearly about the intended research or project
It should be straight forward document, uncluttered with extraneous and irrelevant information
It should also be clearly organized, simple and presented in a logical form</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-1-types-of-proposals">6.1 TYPES OF PROPOSALS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-1-types-of-proposals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="6-1-1-research-proposal">6.1.1 Research proposal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-1-1-research-proposal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Here, the researcher proposes to undertake a piece of research on some pertinent issue</li>
<li>Other research proposals may be academic oriented but are still aimed at undertaking research to solve a problem. i.e. action oriented research</li>
<li>Though most components found in an academic research proposal would also be relevant in one which is not, some section may not be relevant and could be left out without affecting the quality of the proposal e.g. not all action oriented research proposals will require hypotheses or theoretical backgrounds</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="6-1-2-project-proposal">6.1.2 Project proposal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-1-2-project-proposal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This refers to a proposal which is not research oriented but is action-oriented and aimed at undertaking certain activities to solve a specific problem</li>
<li>The differences between a project proposal and a research proposal focus on expected outcome and implementation process</li>
<li>In a research project, the outcome will be data which can be used as a basis of proposing a project or data which will contribute to knowledge and forms the basis recommendations and action</li>
<li>In a project proposal, a specific problem will have been solved</li>
<li>In a research proposal data collection and analysis is carried out and a research report is written</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>In a project proposal, proposed strategies and activities are implemented and eventually evaluation will be conducted to ensure that the project's objectives were met.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-components-of-a-research-proposal">6.2 COMPONENTS OF A RESEARCH PROPOSAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-components-of-a-research-proposal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>There are main sections of a proposal which are considered mandatory and which should be included regardless of ones discipline</li>
<li>These are:</li>
<li>a) An introduction section which includes the background to the problem, the statement of the problem, the purpose, objectives and justification of the study</li>
<li>b) A literature review section where the researcher reviews literature related to the topic under investigation</li>
<li>c) A methodology section which includes the description of the research design, population, sample and sampling techniques, data collection procedures and methods of analysis</li>
<li>d) A time schedule in which the researcher explains the time period needed to carry out the research</li>
<li>e) A budget</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-1-abstract">6.2.1 Abstract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-1-abstract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A proposal abstract is one paragraph summary of what the researcher intends to do</li>
<li>It should be brief, precise and to the point</li>
<li>It gives the reader an overview of what the problem is and how the researcher intends to solve the problem through the proposed research</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-2-introduction">6.2.2 Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-2-introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a very important component of a proposal</li>
<li>A well written introduction tells a lot about what to follow in the rest of the proposal</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>An introduction section should include the background of the problem, the statement of the problem, the purpose of the study, the objectives or research questions, hypotheses, rationale, or justification of the study, the limitations and underlying assumptions, the theoretical framework or conceptual model, wherever possible, and theoretical definition of terms</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-3-the-background-of-the-problem">6.2.3 The background of the problem<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-3-the-background-of-the-problem" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcher should broadly introduce the topic under investigation</li>
<li>This is where a global, regional and national overview of the research topic is briefly discussed. E.g. if the research topic is female education in Kenya, the research should give an overview of the status of female education globally, regionally (ie in Africa) and nationally (ie Kenyan experience)</li>
<li>This enables the reader to have an idea of what is happening regarding the area under investigation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-4-the-problem-statement">6.2.4 The problem statement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-4-the-problem-statement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After describing the background of the problem the researcher should narrow down the focus and state the problem under investigation. This section is referred to as â€œthe problem statement sectionâ€</li>
<li>Here the researcher dates the problem under investigation e.g. high - dropout rates among female pupils in primary schools.</li>
<li>The researcher would elaborate on the consequences of girls dropping out of school</li>
<li>The problem statement should be brief and precise</li>
<li>It should range from half a paragraph to two pages</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 90</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-5-the-purpose-of-the-study">6.2.5 The purpose of the study<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-5-the-purpose-of-the-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A purpose is a broad statement indicating what the researcher intends to do about the problem being investigated</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-6-formats-of-writing-the-purpose-of-the-study">6.2.6 Formats of writing the purpose of the study<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-6-formats-of-writing-the-purpose-of-the-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>State the purpose of the study at the end of the problem statement section
E.g â€œ...based on the problem stated, the purpose of the study is to...â€</li>
<li>A purpose statement is declarative and uses verbs to describe the intended task.</li>
<li>The researcher decides to have a separate sub-section on purpose statement</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-7-objectives-of-the-study">6.2.7 Objectives of the study<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-7-objectives-of-the-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Objectives should be stated clearly and should be testable</li>
<li>The difference between the purpose statement and the objectives is that the purpose statement is broad, while the objectives are derived from the purpose statement and are more specific</li>
<li>Objectives are very crucial in any research study mainly because
i. Objectives determine the kind of questions which will be asked
ii. The objectives determine the data collection and analysis procedures to be used</li>
<li>It is therefore important for the objectives to be clear and unambiguous and brief</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-8-research-questions">6.2.8 Research questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-8-research-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Research questions refer to questions which a researcher would like answered by undertaking the study</li>
</ul>
<p>The difference between research questions and objectives is that a research question is stated in a question form while an objective is a statement
In a study proposal, either research question or objectives should be included
However it is possible to have objectives and research questions in a proposal but only when the objectives are broader and the research questions more specific</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-9-hypothesis">6.2.9 Hypothesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-9-hypothesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It may be directional or non-directional</li>
<li>A researcher is able to state a directional hypothesis when some information on the phenomenon under study is available</li>
<li>Such information is derived from past experience, literature review or existing theories</li>
<li>Some researchers may include hypothesis in their proposals simple because is explanatory</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-10-theoretical-background-or-framework">6.2.10 Theoretical background or framework<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-10-theoretical-background-or-framework" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcher may be interested in ascertaining or testing a particular theory or framework. E.g the argument behind the systems theory, is that a system consists of various components or subsystems which must function together for the system to work</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-11-conceptual-framework">6.2.11 Conceptual framework<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-11-conceptual-framework" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Refers to when a researcher conceptualizes the relationship between variables in the study and shows the relationship graphically or diagrammatically</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-12-rationale-or-justification-and-significance-of-the-study">6.2.12 Rationale or justification and significance of the study<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-12-rationale-or-justification-and-significance-of-the-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s  t  u  d  o  c  u</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>This section highlights the reasons for conducting the study as well as the importance of carrying out.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-2-13-limitations-and-assumptions">6.2.13 Limitations and Assumptions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-2-13-limitations-and-assumptions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-0-data-analysis-and-presentation">7.0 DATA ANALYSIS AND PRESENTATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-0-data-analysis-and-presentation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-1-qualitative-data-presentation-and-analysis">7.1 QUALITATIVE DATA PRESENTATION AND ANALYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-1-qualitative-data-presentation-and-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Data presentation and analysis of qualitative research is quite different from data collected when using quantitative methods</li>
<li>This is because qualitative research uses words while quantitative uses numbers</li>
<li>The following steps could be used when presenting and analyzing qualitative data:-</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="7-1-1-organizing-the-data">7.1.1 Organizing the data<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-1-1-organizing-the-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The data collected is usually large, therefore the researcher will need to put all this information in a simple format. This is called "clearing" the data</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="7-1-2-creating-categories-themes-and-patterns">7.1.2 Creating categories; themes and patterns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-1-2-creating-categories-themes-and-patterns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The disorganized and fragmented data needs to be put into categories, themes and patterns. One can use research questions or discussion topics</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="7-1-3-analyzing-and-interpreting-the-data">7.1.3 Analyzing and interpreting the data<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-1-3-analyzing-and-interpreting-the-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Once themes, categories and patterns have been identified, the researcher then evaluates the data to determine its usefulness and accuracy. Computer programmes can be used to generate themes and categories</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="7-1-4-writing-the-report">7.1.4 Writing the report<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-1-4-writing-the-report" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Unlike in quantitative research where the report writing is done after analyzing the data, in quantitative research techniques, the report writing and the analysis go hand in hand</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-quantitative-data-presentation-and-analysis">7.2 QUANTITATIVE DATA PRESENTATION AND ANALYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-quantitative-data-presentation-and-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>7.2.1 Descriptive statistics</p>
<ul>
<li>This is the process of organizing, summarizing and visualizing quantitative data</li>
<li>The purpose of descriptive statistics is to help the researcher to visualize and identify the patterns that may emerge from the data collected. This in turn assists the researcher in making meaningful conclusions from the results of the study.</li>
<li>Type of statistics or indices used depend on type of variable and scale of measurement (Nominal, ordinal, interval, or rational)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="main-types-of-descriptive-statistics">Main types of descriptive statistics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#main-types-of-descriptive-statistics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="7-2-1-1-measures-of-central-tendency">7.2.1.1 Measures of central tendency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-1-1-measures-of-central-tendency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures of central tendency (mean, mode, median) are statistics that describe the average, typical or most common value for a group of data</li>
<li>A measure of central tendency summarizes a frequency distribution by the use of a single number</li>
<li>There are 3 main types of commonly used measures of central tendency</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-the-mode">a. The mode<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-the-mode" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Def: This is the most commonly occurring value or category among a sample of subjects</li>
<li>This is the only measure of central tendency appropriate for nominal data. Mode may also be reported for ordinal, interval or ratio</li>
<li>A set of data with one value that occurs most frequently is unimodal. Two is biomodal and if more than two values occurring more frequently it is multimodal. It is possible to have no mode. 358991011 9=mode</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-the-median">b. The median<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-the-median" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Page 93</p>
<p>This document is available on  studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>This is the score that divides ranked scores into two equal parts, such that half of the scores are larger than the median and the other half are smaller</p>
<p>Median is appropriate for ordinal, interval and ratio data influenced by extreme values. Media is frequently used in reporting average income because extreme values do not affect the median.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-mean">c. Mean<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-mean" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This means the average of a set of scores or measurements</p>
<p>It is most frequently used measure of central tendency,</p>
<p>Is arrived at by adding all values and dividing by the total number of values</p>
<p>The mean is appropriate for interval and ratio data</p>
<p>It is the most stable measure of central tendency for these levels of data if the distribution is normal</p>
<p>If the distribution is not normal and extreme values are present, the mean will not represent an accurate picture of the distribution.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-2-2-measures-of-variability-measures-dispersion">7.2.2.2 Measures of variability (measures dispersion)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-2-2-measures-of-variability-measures-dispersion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Measures of variability described how spreads out values are a distribution of values. Variability is the distribution of scores around a particular central score or value (usually the mean)</p>
<p>Although measures of central tendency are important, sometimes it may be interesting to know how spreads out the values are in the distribution.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="for-example">For example<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The following are pulse rates of subjects 2 groups (A and B)</p>
<p>Group A-80,79,78,78,75 mean 390/5=78</p>
<p>Group B- 100,90,80,70,50 mean 390/5=78</p>
<p>For this example, the pulse rates for both is 78. However the pulse of group A seems homogeneous, or alike, while group B are heterogeneous, or dissimilar. This information is very important</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>because the arithmetic mean is not appropriate to use in describing group B or to use in comparing the two groups of pulse rates
The most common measures of variability are range, standard deviation, variance, percentile and 2-5 scores</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-measures-of-variability">Types of measures of variability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-measures-of-variability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-range">i. Range<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-range" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the difference between the highest and the lowest value in the group of values or scores in a distribution</li>
<li>This is determined by subtracting the lowest value from the highest score. E.g scores 78,79,80,81,82,85. The range is 85-78</li>
<li>A small range signifies that scores are not spread out and vice versa</li>
<li>Range is used to gain a quick picture of the dispersion of data. Range has limited usefulness because one extreme score can change the range drastically</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-standard-deviation-and-the-variance">ii. Standard deviation and the variance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-standard-deviation-and-the-variance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Standard deviation is defined as the extent to which scores I a distribution deviate from their mean average</li>
<li>The standard deviation therefore involves subtracting the mean from each score to obtain the deviation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-2-3-frequency-distribution">7.2.2.3 Frequency distribution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-2-3-frequency-distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is one of the simplest ways to present data</li>
<li>Frequencies are obtained by simply counting the occurrences of values or scores represented in the data</li>
<li>Frequency distribution are appropriate for reporting all level of data (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio)</li>
<li>In a frequency distribution, all values or scores are listed and the number of times each appears is recorded</li>
<li>Values may be listed from the highest to the lowest or vice versa</li>
<li>Use slash method(////) and if range is small, say less than 20, each score may be listed individually</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>&gt; Groups of scores must be exhaustive (include all possible values) and mutually exclusive(no overlapping of categories) e.g.
&gt; pulse rate  tally frequency
&gt; 60-65  ///  3
&gt; 66-70  ///  5
&gt; 71-75  /// // 7/15</p>
<ul>
<li>Frequency distributions may be described according to their shape</li>
<li>They can be symmetrical or non-symmetrical</li>
<li>Symmetrical distributions are those in which both values of the distribution are the same</li>
<li>Non-symmetrical distribution also called skewed are those in which distribution has an off-centre peak</li>
<li>Skewness- is a measure of horizontal departure from normal distribution. it can be positive skew or negative skew
&gt; Positive skew- is where the tail of the measures of a particular variable are low with very few high measures
&gt; Negative skew- is where the tail of the distribution points to the left i.e. the majority of the scores/measures of a variable are very high and very few low measures</li>
<li>A variable that tends to be positively skewed is personal income while few earn large income. An example of a negatively skewed distribution would be age of people who have chronic illnesses. (a few young and middle aged men and women have chronic illnesses, but many elderly people have chronic conditions.</li>
<li>A part from skewness, another deviation from the standard normal curve is kurtosis-is the vertical departure from the normal</li>
<li>This is the peakedness or the flatness of a curve</li>
<li>A curve that is peaked is called leptokurtic</li>
<li>A relatively flat curve is said to be platykurtic. The kurtosis of the standard curve lies between the two extreme and is called mesokurtic.</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>7.2.2.4 Characteristics of a Normal curve</p>
<ol>
<li>It is well shaped with symmetrical distribution and the maximum height being the mean</li>
<li>The mean, median, and mode are the same</li>
<li>Most values cluster around the mean</li>
<li>T</li>
<li>The tails of the curve never touch the base because the distribution is theoretical, rather than empirical
N/B : normal distribution is frequently found in many happenings in nature. Height and weight are normally distributed in the population</li>
</ol>
<p>7.2.3 GRAPHIC PRESENTATION OF FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION</p>
<ul>
<li>A graph enables the reader to see the trend of the distribution easily than is possible by simply looking at numbers in a frequency distribution</li>
<li>A graph should be labeled on both the vertical and horizontal axes. It should also have a title</li>
<li>Graphs commonly used to present data in research reports include: histograms, frequency polygons, and bar charts.</li>
</ul>
<p>7.2.3.1 Histograms</p>
<ul>
<li>Histograms consists of a series of adjacent bars whose x-axis represent the number of subjects obtaining a particular score, number of respondents belonging to a particular category. X-axis usually has the scores</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 97</p>
<p>This document is available on studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Exact limits are commonly used to construct a histogram hence the bars are continuous with no space in between</p>
<p>Example below is a distribution scores from a test..</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Score limits</th><th>exact limits</th><th>frequency (f)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>91-100</td><td>90.5-100.5</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td>81-90</td><td>80.5-90.5</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>71-80</td><td>70.5-80.5</td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>61-70</td><td>60.5-70.5</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>51-60</td><td>50.5-60.5</td><td>14</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>N=34</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Figure 1. Histogram derived from the score above</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7-2-3-1-frequency-polygons">7.2.3.1 Frequency polygons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-3-1-frequency-polygons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A polygon is a many-sided figure. To plot a frequency polygon, one must establish the midpoint of the class interval
The midpoint is established by summing up the lower and upper class limits of each interval then divide by 2. The midpoint are then plotted against the frequencies and the points are joined using straight lines
A frequency polygon is a closed figure and so the ends meet the horizontal line one limit after the highest and score and one unit from the lowest score</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="example">Example<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Table 2: Distribution of scores from</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Scores</th><th>Midpoints</th><th>Frequency</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10-20</td><td>15</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>20-30</td><td>25</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>30-40</td><td>35</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>40-50</td><td>45</td><td>5</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Figure 2: Frequency polygon constructed from data in table 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7-2-3-2-bar-charts">7.2.3.2 Bar charts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-3-2-bar-charts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Bar charts are preferred when data is discrete or categorized or when the scale is nominal.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> This is because the categories in a nominal scale do not imply any order</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Bar chart is very similar to the histogram except that spaces are left between the bars to signify a lack of continuity or flow between the categories</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Table 3: Department enrolment</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Subject category</th><th>frequency(f)</th><th>%frequency</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Biology</td><td>5</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>Maths</td><td>20</td><td>40</td></tr><tr><td>Geography</td><td>20</td><td>40</td></tr><tr><td>History</td><td>5</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>N=50</td><td>100</td></tr></tbody></table>
