<p>7.2.3.4 Choosing a graph</p>
<ul>
<li>For discrete variables a bar chart is better</li>
<li>Frequency polygons have an advantage that several polygons can be superimposed with less crossing of lines</li>
<li>This allows for comparisons among various distributions</li>
<li>Histograms are easier to understand especially when only one distribution is being represented</li>
<li>However, histograms give the impression that subjects fitting within each interval are evenly distributed over the interval which is not always the case</li>
</ul>
<p>7.2.3.5 Percentages</p>
<ul>
<li>A percentage is defined as the proportion of a subgroup to the total group or sample and range from 0% to 100%</li>
<li>The size of the total group on which percentages is useful or valid should be big. A minimum number should be at least 20</li>
</ul>
<p>7.3 INFERENTIAL STATISTICS</p>
<ul>
<li>These are statistics that use sample data to make decisions or "inferences" about a population inferential statistics are concerned with determining how likely it is for results obtained from a sample to results expected from the entire population</li>
<li>There are many statistical techniques used in testing hypotheses</li>
<li>The commonest ones include:</li>
<li>Correlation - used to analyze the degree of relationship between two variables. There are various correlation techniques that are normally used</li>
<li>Chi-square(xÂ²) - is a statistical technique which attempts to establish relationship between two variables both of which are categorical in nature</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 100</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>e.g. to test the hypotheses that there is a relationship between gender and number of road accidents caused by drivers, here "gender" is categorized as "male" and "female" and no. of accidents is categorized as "no", "few" and "many"</p>
<p>iii. Regression- this is used when a researcher is interested in finding out whether an independent variable predicts or given dependent variable</p>
<p>&gt; Regression the researcher can deal with one dependent variable and one dependant variable (simple regression) or a group of variables together and a dependant variable (multiply regression)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example-of-simple-regression">Example of simple regression<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example-of-simple-regression" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A researcher might be interested in finding out whether education predicts the financial status of households</p>
<p>Education is independent variable while financial status is the dependent variable</p>
<p>Other inferential statistics include analysis of variance(ANOVA)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="n-b">N/B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-choice-of-test-of-hypotheses-depends-on">The choice of test of hypotheses depends on:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-choice-of-test-of-hypotheses-depends-on" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Sample size- some tests cannot be used if sample is too small e.g. regression
ii. Types of variables and measurements- most data analysis procedures are suitable for variables measured at interval or ratio scales. Some are suitable for variables measured at ordinal or nominal scales
iii. Types of research design- for example, data from experimental study that compares differences between two or more groups is best analyzed using analysis of variance(ANOVA)</p>
<p>&gt; Relationships and predictions among variables are best determined using correlation and regression techniques.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-4-research-errors">7.4 RESEARCH ERRORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-4-research-errors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="there-are-two-types-of-errors-that-can-occur">There are two types of errors that can occur:-<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#there-are-two-types-of-errors-that-can-occur" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>i. Type I Error</p>
<p>This occurs when there is rejection of null hypotheses when its true e.g. there is no relationship between tribe and level of intelligence if this is true and you reject it, you have committed a type I error</p>
<p>ii. Type II error</p>
<p>Occurs in acceptance of null hypothesis when it is false e.g if the above statement is false and you accept it then you have committed a type 2 error.</p>
<p>8.0 COMMUNICATING THE RESEARCH FINDINGS</p>
<ul>
<li>The significance of conducting research is to communicate and share the research findings.</li>
<li>There are several ways of communicating research findings.</li>
</ul>
<p>These are:-</p>
<p>i. A written report for academic purposes e.g. thesis or desertion which are requirements for obtaining a certain academic level
ii. A written report prepared for some managers and policy implementers-present a clear and detailed report with no academic jargons
iii. A written report sent as an article for publication in referred/non-referred journals
iv. Presentation of the research findings in workshops, seminars and conferences</p>
<p>8.1 PRESENTING RESEARCH RESULTS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES</p>
<ul>
<li>Because publication in journals which is referred takes long (up to 3 years), presentation of research findings is more rapid in distribution of study results</li>
<li>Presentation should be in nursing conferences as well as interdisciplinary conferences</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 102</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Research results can be presented at professional conferences in two ways</p>
<p>a) Oral presentation
b) Poster presentation- has become more popular</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Potential participants are contacted through â€œcall for abstractsâ€
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> The call for abstracts is a request for a summary for a study that the researcher wishes to present at a conference
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> These requests are published in professional journals and distributed to educational institutions, health care agencies and potential participants from professional organizations notices of research
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Conferences are generally distributed 6-12 months before the event.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Each conference or seminar provide guidelines for presenters and for submission of abstracts
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Abstract length varies from 50-1000 words, but many have 200-300 word limitations
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> It contains the purpose, research question(s), hypothesis, design, methodology, major findings and conclusions
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Generally, those selected to participate receive no pay and are required to cover their own travel expenses
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> In some cases conference registration fee is waived or reduced for participants</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-2-presenting-a-research-paper">8.2 PRESENTING A RESEARCH PAPER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-2-presenting-a-research-paper" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> An oral presentation of a research report is usually referred to as paper presentation. Paper because it has been written on paper and is read by the investigator.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> If principal investigator is unable to attend the conference, a co-investigator or another person familiar with the study presents the paper.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Presenting research results at a conference has advantages</p>
<p>Page 103</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s  t  u  d  o  c  u</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>i. The researcher presents findings that are current/recent unlike publication that lags behind for up to 3 years
ii. The researcher has an opportunity to interact with those people who are interested in the study and will be able to locate other researchers who are studying the same or similar phenomena</p>
<ul>
<li>The presenter is usually given 10-15 minutes. Sometimes additional time is allocated for questions or during break, other questions are dealt with.</li>
<li>Format for oral presentation is the same as that of the journal but condensation of material is done to fit the time given.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-3-presenting-a-research-poster">8.3 PRESENTING A RESEARCH POSTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-3-presenting-a-research-poster" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Has become popular. This is a visual method of presentation</li>
<li>During a poster session, the presenters usually remain with their posters and interact with viewers</li>
<li>Posters sessions generally are held during research conferences where oral presentations are also given. 1-2 hours is devoted to posters. Some conferences may have only poster presentation</li>
<li>Poster presentation sessions are an excellent way for beginning research to â€˜get their feet wetâ€™ is not scary as standing up in front of an audience and orally discussing a study</li>
<li>Sizes of posters vary according to different research conference requirements. Common size is 4 feet by 8 feet</li>
<li>Posters should be carefully constructed, colour combinations should be used to be attractive</li>
<li>Posters should contain the research problem, hypothesis, research question, description of the sample, methods, findings, major conclusions</li>
<li>Do not put too much material on a poster, diagrams, graphs, and tables are effective means of presenting certain aspects of the study such as findings</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-0-publication-of-a-journal-article">9.0 PUBLICATION OF A JOURNAL ARTICLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-0-publication-of-a-journal-article" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The growth of the nursing profession depends on the ability of its members to share a body of knowledge</li>
<li>Nursing research is the method of building the knowledge and publications are the major medium for sharing this knowledge</li>
<li>Research should be conducted with the idea of publication in mind</li>
<li>A few journals pay authors a per-page fee. Generally authors do not receive any compensation</li>
<li>Authors may pay for any revisions they may wish to be made on the galleys received</li>
<li>Galley proofs are sheets of paper showing how the article will appear in type set format</li>
<li>Some journals provide an author with several complimentary copies of the issue in which the article appears</li>
<li>When an author receives an acceptance letter from a journal, an appropriate date or month of publication is usually included. (1 month-3 years lag)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-1-preparing-the-article">9.1 PREPARING THE ARTICLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-1-preparing-the-article" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Length of journal varies but most editions prefer articles of 10-15 typed page.</li>
<li>The format and sections vary according to the journal parts including introduction, literature review, methods, findings and discussion</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 105</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 106</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-2-selecting-a-journal">9.2 SELECTING A JOURNAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-2-selecting-a-journal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Selecting an appropriate journal is an important decision</li>
<li>Check local and international journal (online) that can publish the research findings</li>
<li>They could be nursing only or nursing and allied journals</li>
<li>The nurse author should not forget magazines designed for the general public</li>
<li>The journal can be referred and non-referred journal.</li>
<li><strong>Referred journal</strong> is one in which subject experts, chosen by journals editorial staff, evaluate manuscripts</li>
<li><strong>Non referred journal</strong>- is one that uses editorial members of staff or consultants to evaluate manuscripts</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-3-sending-query-letters">9.3 SENDING QUERY LETTERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-3-sending-query-letters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Before submitting an article at a journal, it may be wise for the author to first determine the journals interest in the manuscript</li>
<li>This is done by a letter of inquiry called query letter</li>
<li>A query letter contains an outline of a manuscript and important information about the manuscript that an author sends to an editor to determine the editor's interest in publishing the material</li>
<li>It should be addressed to the editor by name</li>
<li>On receiving the query, the editor may;</li>
<li>Request for submission of manuscript or</li>
<li>Suggestions for revision in the manuscript then submission or</li>
<li>Discourage submission of the manuscript</li>
<li>Many journals require a signed statement that the manuscript is not being considered by any other journal</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 107</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-4-reasons-for-rejection-of-the-manuscript">9.4 REASONS FOR REJECTION OF THE MANUSCRIPT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-4-reasons-for-rejection-of-the-manuscript" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>i. Poorly written manuscript
ii. Poorly developed idea, not consistent with purpose of journal
iii. Methodology problems
iv. Content undocumented, content inaccurate e.t.c.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-0-utilization-of-nursing-research-findings">10.0 UTILIZATION OF NURSING RESEARCH FINDINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-0-utilization-of-nursing-research-findings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The use research findings in nursing practice is called research utilization</li>
<li>In the past, many actions of nurses have been based on tradition or authority. This is no longer acceptable in this day of evidence-based practice. Nurses should be able to justify the discussions they make and the care they give</li>
<li>Barriers to the utilization of nursing research have been identified with means to bridge them</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="these-barriers-include">These barriers include:-<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#these-barriers-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-nurses-lack-of-knowledge">i. Nurses lack of knowledge<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-nurses-lack-of-knowledge" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Many nurses are unaware of many research findings. Role models in research for less experienced stuff, create nursing research department, creation of formal nursing committee and presentation of research grand round are just but few suggested ways to improve utilization.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-nurses-negative-attitudes">ii. Nurses negative attitudes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-nurses-negative-attitudes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Negative attitudes towards research has contributed to underutilization of research findings</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on
S
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Can be addressed by having role models in clinical area who value research, have research courses at all levels of education and also having faulty with positive attitudes who help students early in their careers.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-inadequate-dissemination-of-research-findings">iii. Inadequate dissemination of research findings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-inadequate-dissemination-of-research-findings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Most nursing research studies are never published or presented at research meetings or workshops</li>
<li>Also those that are published or presented are not written or verbally presented at a level where the practicing nurse can understand the findings.</li>
<li>Many practicing nurses complain about their ability to understand articles in the research journals, language is technical and length for researchers rather than for clinicians</li>
<li>Researchers in academic settings are sometimes rewarded for publication in practice journals</li>
<li>Nurses need to publish in popular journals, make research findings understandable. Also consider publication and presentation for the lay media to counter this problem</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-lack-of-institutional-support">iv. Lack of institutional support<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-lack-of-institutional-support" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Nurses frequently perceive that there is little institutional support for nursing research</li>
<li>To remove this barrier, nurses should get time off to attend nursing conferences; institutions should make available current journals available in the institutionâ€™s library and allocating time for nurses to read research reports during the workday.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="v-findings-are-not-ready-for-use-in-practice">v. Findings are not ready for use in practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-findings-are-not-ready-for-use-in-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Study findings is not something that can be crammed over night and ingested in the morning</li>
<li>No study findings should be implemented if the study has not been replicated in several clinical settings, with similar results being found</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>For research findings to be ready for use in practice, the findings must have been replicated at least once and demonstrated to be true with "red" patients as well with "normal" subjects</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-0-the-role-of-the-nurses-in-research">11.0 THE ROLE OF THE NURSES IN RESEARCH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-0-the-role-of-the-nurses-in-research" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are many roles that nurses can assume in association with research projects. These include;</p>
<ol>
<li>Principal investigator</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Nurses can serve as principal investigators in scientific investigations. However one needs special research preparations nurses can also conduct small-scale survey study.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Member of a research team</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Nurses can serve as members of research team. They may act as data collectors or administer the experimental intervention of the study</li>
<li>As nurses participate in research interest in research increases and the enthusiasm to conduct their own research grow</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Identifier of researchable problems</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Nurses of all levels, have responsibility of trying to identify areas of needed research</li>
<li>Nurses at the bedside are particularly well situated to identify patient related researchable problem</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Evaluator of research findings</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Every nurse should be involved in the evaluation of research findings. As research consumers, nurses have the obligation to become familiar with research findings and determine the usefulness of these findings in the practice area</li>
<li>Beginning researches should antique research articles with experienced researchers and eventually on their own</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 109</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s  t  u  d  o  c  u</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Evaluation of research is not an easy task and one needs to acquire some of the skills needed to antique research articles and reports</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-user-of-research-findings">5. User of research findings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-user-of-research-findings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After evaluating research findings, nurses should use relevant findings in their practice</li>
<li>The primary goal of nursing research is improved care to patients/clients</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-patient-client-advocate-during-studies">6. Patient/client advocate during studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-patient-client-advocate-during-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>All nurses have the responsibility to act as patient/client advocates when their patient/clients are involved in research</li>
<li>The advocacy involves making sure that the ethical aspects of research are upheld</li>
<li>Nurses might help in explaining a study to potential participants before study begins</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-subject-in-studies">7. Subject in studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-subject-in-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nurses can act as subjects in research. Issues about nurses welfare or work place issues such as motivation among others can be done nurses being subjects of study</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-0-writing-research-reports">12.0 WRITING RESEARCH REPORTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-0-writing-research-reports" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The research report contains:</p>
<ul>
<li>Title</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Dedication (optional)
Abstract
Table of contents
List of tables
List of figures
List of abbreviation and acronyms
Executive summary (optional)
Introduction
Literature review
Methodology
Results and discussion
Summary, conclusions and recommendations
References
Acknowledgement
Appendices</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-1-title">12.1 TITLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-1-title" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Should be short and simple - 12-15 words maximum</li>
<li>Should contain key words that others will use when searching the topic</li>
<li>It gives the reader some initial information about the area of research the report has covered</li>
<li>It should give the major variables of the research, the target population and possibly the geographical location e.g. the research</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 111</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>It is the selling point as it will determine whether someone will read your article</li>
<li>The authorship must be only</li>
<li>Someone who contributed to the design, data collection, analysis or interpretation of the findings</li>
<li>Contributed to the writing or editing of the final manuscript</li>
<li>Agrees with the findings and is willing to stand up in public and defend the work</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-2-dedication-optional">12.2 Dedication (optional)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-2-dedication-optional" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Some researchers dedicate their work to persons whom they see as special to their lives</li>
<li>May be spouse, children, parents or very dear friends</li>
<li>Some researchers give reasons for their dedication</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-3-abstract">12.3 Abstract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-3-abstract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is a reflection of the salient findings of the research study (it is an overview)</li>
<li>It contains purpose of the study, the population studied, major results and conclusion of the study</li>
<li>Should not be more than half a page</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-4-table-of-contents">12.4 Table of contents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-4-table-of-contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A table of contents is like a map that guides reader in locating various sections of the research report</li>
<li>It contains the chapter teaching, main headings and subheadings and corresponding page of each in the body of the document</li>
<li>It is necessary for location of desired section quickly</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-5-list-of-tables">12.5 List of tables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-5-list-of-tables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This list of tables has a format like that of the table of contents.</li>
<li>The number and title of each table appearing in the body of report is listed together with corresponding page number</li>
<li>Used for easy tracing of tables</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-6-list-of-figures">12.6 List of figures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-6-list-of-figures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Figures such as graphs, charts, diagrams and photographs may be used in research</li>
<li>Their list as they appear in the body of the report</li>
<li>The list should clearly give the number and title of the figure and its number</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-7-list-of-abbreviations-and-acronyms">12.7 List of abbreviations and acronyms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-7-list-of-abbreviations-and-acronyms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>These abbreviations are used especially where a ward or a group of words is used repeatedly</li>
<li>The abbreviations and acronyms should be listed and explained in full</li>
<li>They should be used only when necessary</li>
<li>Refer on guidelines on use of abbreviations</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-8-executive-summary-advisable-to-include">12.8 Executive summary (Advisable to include)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-8-executive-summary-advisable-to-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is short version or a summary of the research report provides a picture of the entire document</li>
<li>A good executive summary begins with a clear and brief statement of the problem</li>
<li>Details from the body of the report are then presented in brief and the summary ends with conclusions and recommendations</li>
<li>Use of bulletins and bolded subheading helps to make summary reader-friendly</li>
<li>Avoid technical terms in the executive summary</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 113</p>
<p>This document is available on studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Page 114</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-9-introduction">12.9 Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-9-introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This has several components that include:</li>
<li>The background of the study</li>
<li>The problem statement</li>
<li>Objectives</li>
<li>Hypotheses</li>
<li>Research questions</li>
<li>Limitations of the study</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-10-literature-review">12.10 Literature Review<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-10-literature-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This provides the needed support to the researcher rationale for undertaking research in a certain area</li>
<li>The critique of findings from other studies done in related areas</li>
<li>Literature review assists the researcher in making a strong care for the study's objectives, research questions or hypotheses</li>
<li>Literature review should be relevant to the topic</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-11-methodology">12.11 Methodology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-11-methodology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It gives regarding the procedures used in conducting the study.</li>
<li>Issues discussed under methodology include the population, sample, sampling techniques, the research design, instruments or tools used in data collection, measurement of variables and techniques to be used in such tests</li>
<li>Give enough details regarding the procedures used in conducting the study should be precise enough to enable other researchers to replicate your study</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-12-results-and-discussion">12.12 Results and Discussion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-12-results-and-discussion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Main purpose of the results and discussion is to present the results of the data analysis in a systematic way</li>
<li>The data analysis is done figures and tables are usually used</li>
<li>Computers and statistical packages has made data analysis easier and faster</li>
<li>In this section, it is advisable to start with a short introduction that describes the general procedure followed in analyzing the data</li>
<li>State the objectives or hypothesis of the study</li>
<li>Key pointers on writing the results and discussion are</li>
</ul>
<p>Present descriptive results of analysis first. They include frequencies, percentages, means, modes, median, and standard deviation e.t.c.</p>
<p>Then present the results of hypotheses tests if any. These tests inform whether results can be generalized to the target population</p>
<p>It may not be possible to present every result of the analysis. Select the most important findings for reporting. Be guided by objectives and hypotheses</p>
<p>Not every result or table generated is presented in the report objectives and hypotheses of the study should guide you to select the most important ones</p>
<p>Graphs, charts and other usual presentations of the data should be included in the results and discussion section of the report if they add value to the content</p>
<p>It is very important for the researcher to point out whether findings are supported by other studies discussed in the literature review section. If findings contradict other studies, point out giving possible reasons for such outcome</p>
<ul>
<li>The discussion section therefore conveys the meaning of the findings to the reader and provides an important linkage to other</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s  t  u  d  o  c  u</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>sections or components of the report such as objectives, hypotheses, research questions or theoretical/framework and existing literature</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-13-summary-conclusions-and-recommendations">12.13 Summary, conclusions and recommendations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-13-summary-conclusions-and-recommendations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Summary reminds and informs the reader about the purpose of study, process used to collect and analyze data and the major findings of the study</li>
<li>A summary must reflect as accurately as possible the body of ones report.</li>
<li>Conclusion answers the questions that sparked the collection and analysis of data</li>
<li>In including the report, it is necessary to discuss the practical application and implications of the findings...</li>
<li>Implications are usually targeted to stakeholders e.g. health policy makers</li>
<li>The summary and conclusions should lead logically to your recommendations must be consistent with the purpose of the study, its objectives, the evidence presented by the data and interpretations given</li>
<li>Recommendations should be practical and achievable</li>
<li>Common recommendations that researchers often make include;</li>
<li>Areas of further research, with the question in that study that remain unanswered, hence ought to be explored further</li>
<li>Methodology issues, that could be addressed and refined to improve future research in that area of the study</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Actions that should be taken to address the problem based on the research findings e.g. interventions/projects</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-14-references">12.14 References<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-14-references" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcher should give credit to authors of any work or materials quoted from or rejected to by listing them</li>
<li>Generally, a reference gives the name of the author, year of publication of the document, the title of the book or journal paper and the publisher</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-15-acknowledgement">12.15 Acknowledgement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-15-acknowledgement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Research process takes a lot of time, money and energy. A researcher may seek help from professional colleagues, respondents, research assistants etc.</li>
<li>One can also seek materials from institutions or organizations</li>
<li>The researcher should acknowledge individuals and organizations that provide assistance</li>
<li>But because they can be many, the researcher should maintain only a few by names to keep the acknowledgement section as short as possible.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-16-appendices">12.16 Appendices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-16-appendices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The appendix section of the report contains information that the researcher does not seem necessary to include in the body of the report</li>
<li>The appendix contents include:-</li>
<li>Instruments of data collection</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 117</p>
<p>This document is available on studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Statistical tables from data analysis</p>
<p>Correspondence related to the study e.g. letters of consent to participate in the study</p>
<p>Letters of approval to conduct the research</p>
<p>Research persists and terms of reference if any.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="references">REFERENCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#references" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="glossary-of-terms">Glossary of terms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glossary-of-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Abstract An abbreviated summary of a research paper, generally at the beginning of the paper.</li>
</ul>
<p>Page 119
This document is available on
Â© studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Action research A style of research in which the researchers work with the people and for the people, rather than undertake research on them. The focus of action research is on generating solutions to problems identified by the people who are going to use the results of research.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Analytical study An observational study that describes associations and analyses them for possible cause and effect.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alternative hypothesis The hypothesis that the researcher is testing in the study. In scientific methodology, we start with the assumption that it is not true until proved otherwise, by rejecting the null hypothesis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assignment The process in an experiment where the researcher allocates subjects to two or more groups, trying to achieve having groups as identical as possible to allow a valid comparison of the results. Matching and random assignment are the two most common methods.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bar or column charts A graphic method of describing the data, where the frequency of a particular category is reflected in the height of the bar in the graph.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bias If the study sample is not representative of the population, the inference we make from the result may be misleading.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blinding A randomized controlled trial may be blinded if participants in the trial are likely to change their behaviour in a systematic way that may influence the outcome of the study when they are aware of which intervention they receive. The term "masking" is often used instead of "blinding".</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Case-control study A type of observational analytical longitudinal retrospective study in which a group of subjects with a specified outcome (cases) and a group without that outcome (controls) are identified. Investigators then compare the extent to which each subject was previously exposed to the variable of interest, such as risk factor, a treatment, or an intervention.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Central tendency The average (mean), middle (median) or most common (mode) score for numerical data in a frequency distribution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cluster sampling A type of random sampling, based first on the random selection of certain subgroups, from which the sample can be taken.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Coding A method of analysis of qualitative data obtained for example in interviews, where categories are labelled to facilitate computer analysis and examination of relationships.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cohort study The term used in clinical and epidemiological research to describe a longitudinal prospective observational study.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Consecutive sampling A sampling procedure in which subjects are selected by taking every individual that presents over a specified period of time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Continuous variables Data which are measured on a continuous scale. They are numbers that can be added, subtracted, multiplied and divided.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cross-sectional study An observational study design in which measurements are made on a single occasion.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Descriptive statistics Statistics designed to summarize and describe characteristics of the data. Descriptive statistics helps us to make sense of a large volume of data.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Descriptive study An observational study that simply describes the distribution of a characteristic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Directional research hypothesis The research hypothesis outlining a relationship may be directional or non-directional. For example, a relationship between smoking and cardiovascular disease can only be directional. It is expected in the hypothesis that it will increase cardiovascular disease. The relationship between oral hormonal contraceptives and certain disease conditions can be non-directional. The disease conditions may increase or decrease as a result of oral hormonal contraceptive use.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Discrete or discontinuous data Numerical variables that are not measured on a continuous scale.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Experimental or intervention study A study design in which the investigators test the effect of an intervention on the events taking place in the study.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>External validity The extent to which the results of the study sample may be generalized to the population from which the sample was withdrawn; also called generalizability.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Focus group discussion A method of qualitative research used when information and insights will be better gained from the interaction of a group than from in-depth interviews with individuals.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Frequency distribution The way in which scores within a given sample are distributed.</li>
<li>Frequency distribution curve A graphic method for summarizing data and looking at them, in which each variable is plotted against the frequency with which it is found.</li>
<li>Frequency distribution table A table that gives the frequency with which a particular value appears in the data.</li>
<li>Hawthorne effect An effect which results in the improvement of subjects' performances through being observed and/or social contact. It is an example of a placebo effect.</li>
<li>Histogram A method of plotting frequency distributions.</li>
<li>Hypothesis The research hypothesis is a tentative statement that can be tested by a scientific research design.</li>
<li>Incidence Incidence rates relate the number of new cases of a condition in a population within a time period.</li>
<li>Independent or input variables Variables that have values that are autonomous of the dependent or outcome variables. Because independent variables precede dependent variables, they are often called predictors. In epidemiology, independent variables are often called risk factors or exposure variables.</li>
<li>Inference A generalization made about a population from the study of a subset or sample of that population.</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on
5
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Informed consent An ethical requirement for participation in a research study, indicating that a competent person, in possession of all the relevant information, freely agrees to participate.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Internal validity The degree to which the investigator's conclusions correctly describe what actually happened in the study. It means that within the confines of the study, results appear to be accurate, the methods and analysis used stand up to scrutiny, and the interpretation of the investigators appears supported.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inter-observer reliability The extent to which observers rating or measuring a particular phenomenon agree with each other.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intra-observer reliability The extent to which an observer rating or measuring a particular phenomenon agrees with her/his rating or measurement when presented with the same task on two different occasions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Likert format A format for closed-response questions used to elicit attitudes of the respondents to a certain statement. The respondent chooses from among five categories: strongly agree, agree, undecided, disagree, strongly disagree.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Literature Previous research done in the area under study.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Longitudinal study An observational study design in which measurements are made over a period of time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Longitudinal prospective study An observational study design in which the investigators follow subjects for future events.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Mean The average of a group of scores. The mean is derived by summing up the individual values and dividing by the total number of measurements.</li>
<li>Median The median of a distribution is a midpoint at which one half of the observations fall below and one half fall above the value.</li>
<li>Mode The most frequent measurement in a distribution.</li>
<li>Normal distribution curve A bell-shaped curve of the frequency distribution of the data.</li>
<li>Null hypothesis In scientific methodology, we do not test the research hypothesis directly.</li>
<li>Instead, we start with an assumption that there is no difference or association between the variables compared. This is called the null hypothesis (H0). If statistical analysis rejects the null hypothesis, it means that the alternative hypothesis is probably true, and that there a difference between the group or a relationship between the variables.</li>
<li>Numerical variables Data expressed in numbers.</li>
<li>Objectivity Objective measures are made in a process involving a minimum amount of human interpretation, for example measurement of height.</li>
<li>Observational study A study design in which the investigators observe and record events taking place in the study.</li>
<li>Open-ended question A question asked without providing a predefined set of responses to select from.</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on
5
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Ordinal categorical data Categorical data in which the variables can be ordered one above another. An example of ordinal categorical data is the number of children a woman has.</li>
<li>P value The probability that a difference or an association as large as the one observed could have occurred by chance alone.</li>
<li>Pie chart A graphical method of representing the frequency distribution of a set of categorical data in the shape of a pie.</li>
<li>Pilot study A preliminary study to test the feasibility of the protocol, before implementing the study proper. It may also be called "pre-test".</li>
<li>Placebo effect The phenomenon where, in an intervention study, subjects receiving, without knowing, an inert drug, show an improvement or perception of improvement in their condition, probably due to their expectations.</li>
<li>Population An entire set of persons, animals, objects or events which the researcher intends to study.</li>
<li>Pre-test A preliminary study to test the feasibility and appropriateness of a questionnaire, before implementing the study proper.</li>
<li>Prevalence The overall occurrence of a particular condition in a specific population at a specific point of time.</li>
<li>Probability The chance or likelihood of an event happening. Probability may vary in value from 0 (no chance) to 1 (certain). Researchers have to set the level of probability/certainty they are willing to accept for their findings.</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Proposal A document written for the purpose of obtaining funding for a research project.</li>
<li>Quality assurance A system to ensure that the study is performed and the data are generated, recorded and reported in compliance with the protocol, good clinical practice and national regulations.</li>
<li>Qualitative methods A research approach that emphasizes the non-numerical data and interpretive analysis.</li>
<li>Quantitative methods A research approach that emphasizes the collection of numerical data or data than can be quantified, and statistical analysis.</li>
<li>Questionnaire A means of collecting data from people where they provide written responses to a set of questions, either in their own words (open-ended questions), or by selecting from among pre-defined answers (closed response questions).</li>
<li>Random sampling A sampling procedure in which a sample is drawn from a population such that each member of the population has had an equal chance of selection. Random sampling is not haphazard sampling.</li>
<li>Range In a group of scores, the range is the difference between the maximum and minimum scores.</li>
<li>Ratio A numerical expression of the relationship between one set of frequencies and another. An example is the ratio of males to females in a sample.</li>
<li>Rate A numerical expression of the frequency of a condition in a given population measured in a specified period of time.</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on
Â© studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Reliability The extent to which a test or measurement result is reproducible.</li>
<li>Representative sample A sample that accurately reflects the characteristics of the population from which it is drawn. It is a precise miniaturized representation of the proportion of elements of the population.</li>
<li>Retrospective study An observational study design in which the investigators study present and past events.</li>
<li>Sample A subset selected for the study from the larger population.</li>
<li>Sampling error The discrepancy between the values obtained from the relatively small sample and the larger population from which the sample was drawn.</li>
<li>Selection bias A systematic difference between people who are selected for a study and those who are not selected.</li>
<li>Standard deviation A measure of the dispersion or variability of a group of scores.</li>
<li>Stratified random sampling A sampling procedure in which the researcher tries to ensure that important subgroups in the population are adequately represented.</li>
<li>Structured interview An interview in which the questions are generally pre-defined, asked in a fixed order and recorded in writing.</li>
<li>Subjective measures Measures involving a substantial degree of human interpretation, for example ratings of pain.</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Systematic sampling A sampling procedure in which subjects are selected by a simple periodic process, for example, selecting every second or third patient.</li>
<li>Validity The extent to which a test measures what it is intended to measure.</li>
<li>Variability The extent to which a group of scores varies or is spread out. This is usually described by a descriptive statistic such as the range or standard deviation.</li>
<li>Variable Statistical term for the score in data.</li>
<li>Variance A measure of the dispersion or variability of a group of scores.</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="research-methods">Research Methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#research-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Nursing Research (Kenya Medical Training College)</p>

<p>MODULE 18: RESEARCH METHODS</p>
<p>CODE: RES 303</p>
<p>Hours:</p>
<p>Credit: 3</p>
<p>Module competency.</p>
<p>This module is designed to enable the learner conduct research in community settings</p>
<p>Module Outcomes</p>
<p>By the end of this module the learner should:</p>
<ol>
<li>Demonstrate understanding of the principles of research and its application in community health</li>
<li>Explain research proposal development stages</li>
<li>Describe data collection techniques</li>
<li>Employ various sampling techniques in collecting data for health research system</li>
<li>Demonstrate understanding of importance of dissemination of results and report writing in research</li>
</ol>
<p>Module units</p>
