<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id=""><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"></span></h1></div>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>âœ“ To identify the social economic status of professionals, women in Mombasa
âœ“ To investigate the factors that influence baby weaning by professional women in Mombasa
âœ“ To explore the attitudes of professional women in Mombasa towards breastfeeding</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-6-formulating-hypotheses">3.6 Formulating hypotheses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-6-formulating-hypotheses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>âœ“ This is the researchers prediction concerning the outcome of the study
âœ“ It states possible differences, relationships or caused between two variables or concepts
âœ“ These derived or based on:
âœ“ Existing theories
âœ“ Personal experiences
âœ“ Previous research
âœ“ A study can have one or more hypotheses. These hypotheses are crucial because that is the study put to empirically test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-6-1-purposes-of-hypothesis">3.6.1 Purposes of Hypothesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-6-1-purposes-of-hypothesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hypothesis provides direction. They bridge the gap between the problem and the evidence needed for its solution</li>
<li>Hypothesis ensure collection of the evidence necessary to answer the question posed in the statement</li>
<li>Hypothesis enable the investigator to assess the information he/she has collected in terms of relevance and organization</li>
<li>Hypothesis permit the researcher to understand the problem with greater clarity and use the data collected to find solutions to problems</li>
<li>Hypothesis from the frame work for the ultimate conclusions as solutions. Researchers usually base their conclusions on the results of the tests of their hypothesis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-a-good-hypothesis">Characteristics of a good hypothesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-a-good-hypothesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) They must state clearly and briefly the expected relationship of variables
b) They must be based on a sound rationale derived from theory, previous research or professional experience</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>c) They should be consistent with common sense or generally accepted truths
d) They must be testable i.e. data can be collected to support or fail to support hypothesis
e) They must be testable within a reasonable time
f) They must be related to empirical phenomena-words to "ought", "should", "bad" should be avoided
g) Variable stated in the hypothesis must be consistent with the purpose statement, objectives and the operationalisation of variables in the method section
h) They should be concise and simple</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. High alcohol content in the blood influences reaction time among drivers in Kenya
ii. There is a relationship between level of education and income among civil servants in Kenya
iii. The amount of rainfall and the type of fertilizer used influences the yield of wheat per area in the Riftvalley province in Kenya</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-6-2-types-of-hypotheses">3.6.2 Types of Hypotheses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-6-2-types-of-hypotheses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-6-2-1-null-hypothesis">3.6.2.1 Null hypothesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-6-2-1-null-hypothesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>â˜‘ Also called statistical hypotheses</li>
<li>â˜‘ These always states that no relationship of differences exists. Any relationship between two variables or differences between groups is merely due to chance or errors</li>
</ul>
<p>e.g. High alcohol content in the blood affects reaction time among truck drivers in Kenya</p>
<ul>
<li>â˜‘ There is a relationship between bhang trafficking and intelligence among traffickers</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-6-2-2-alternative-directional-hypotheses">3.6.2.2 Alternative directional hypotheses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-6-2-2-alternative-directional-hypotheses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>â˜‘ This specifies the relationship or differences between variables. The relationship may be stated as either being higher than or lower than e.t.c. e.g. Male circumcision reduces the prospection of contracting HIV infection among males in Nyanza province.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="literature-review">LITERATURE REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#literature-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This document is available on
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>This involves the systematic identification, location and analysis of documents containing information related to the research problem being investigated</p>
<p><strong>It should be extensive and thorough:</strong></p>
<p><strong>PURPOSE OF LITERATURE REVIEW</strong></p>
<p>i. The main purpose is to determine what has been done on the problem being studied
ii. This avoids unnecessary and unintentional duplications
iii. Demonstrates one's familiarizing with existing body of knowledge gives the reader confidence
iv. Identify consistently unproductive or unreliable approaches
v. Reveals information gaps and unanswered questions
vi. Reveals strategies procedures and measuring instruments useful in the investigations of the research problem. This helps one to avoid mistakes that have been made by other researchers and also helps one to benefit from other researchers experience.
vii. Literature review will suggest other procedures, approaches, and other recommendations which one can try
viii. Makes the researcher familiar with previous studies thus facilitates interpretation of the study results. Results can be discussed in terms of whether they support or contrast previous findings. If contradicting literature review may provide rationale for the discrepancy.
ix. Literature review helps the researcher to narrow or limit the research problem and to define it better. The literature will give the researcher the knowledge needed to convert a tentative research problem into a detailed and concise plan of work
x. It helps determine new approaches and stimulates new ideas. The researcher may also be alerted to research possibilities which have been overlooked into the past.</p>
<p><strong>FACTORS TO CONSIDER WHEN DOING LITERATURE</strong></p>
<p>i. Assess the strengths and weakness of past management
ii. Report any inconsistent findings
iii. Identify gaps in the knowledge
iv. Determine the contribution of proposed study
v. Consider the possibility of unintentional duplication</p>
<p><strong>SCOPE OF LITERATURE REVIEW</strong></p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Questions arising from the scope include:</p>
<ul>
<li>How wide or narrow should it be?</li>
<li>What is the relevance to my topic?</li>
</ul>
<p>These are applicable questions and they get answered with experience. There is no formula for arriving at a decision. However these hints are useful towards determining scope</p>
<p>i. In widely researched area, cover a narrow topic in depth e.g. HIV
ii. In a little or new researched areas, where little depth available, the researcher would require to review any relevant material in order to develop a logical framework for the study and appropriate hypotheses for the study
iii. Avoid the temptation to include all available materials. Excessive material does not mean great research information
iv. At the point of saturation reencountering already reviewed literature, abandon literature review.</p>
<p>TIPS ON GOOD LITERATURE REVIEW</p>
<p>a) Avoid hurried review, you may overlook important studies
b) Avoid relying too much on secondary sources
c) Concentrate on the methodology and measurements used and not only findings
d) Copy references correctly and constantly acknowledge sources</p>
<p>STEPS OF LITERATURE REVIEW</p>
<ol>
<li>Be familiar with the library-before beginning the literature review</li>
<li>Make a list of key words or phrases to guide your search e.g. female condoms, abortions, community health, episiotomy</li>
<li>Go to the source of the literature</li>
<li>Summarize the references on cards for easy organization of the literature</li>
<li>Analyze, organize and report the collected data in orderly manner. This is usually the hardest part</li>
<li>Make an outline of the main topics or themes in order of presentation. Decide on the number of headlines and sub headlines required depending on how detailed the review is</li>
<li>Analyze each reference in terms of the outline made and establish where it will be most relevant</li>
</ol>
<p>This document is available on
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Studies contrary to the received wisdom should not be ignored, such studies should be analyzed and possible explanation for the differences given</li>
<li>Literature should be organized in such a way that more general issues covered first before the researcher narrows down to that which is more specific to the research problem</li>
<li>Some researchers prefer to have a brief summary of the literature and its implications. However this is optional.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sources-of-literature">SOURCES OF LITERATURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sources-of-literature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Primary sources:</strong> These are accounts of those who actually observed or witnessed the occurrence of the phenomena</p>
<p>It also includes accounts of primary researchers (original documents)</p>
<p>These should be used as much as possible because secondary sources may be attended by writers</p>
<p><strong>Secondary sources:</strong> These include publication of authors who were not direct observers or participants of the events described. Examples of sources of literature/information;</p>
<p><strong>Scholarly journals:</strong> Are crucial research documents. Are found in the libraries. They can also be found in the internet</p>
<p><strong>These and dissertations:</strong> These are research projects written by masters and PhD students. They are valuable sources of information.</p>
<p><strong>Government documents:</strong> These include policy papers and research reports owned government e.g. Kenya demographic and Health survey, vision 2030</p>
<p><strong>Papers presented at conferences:</strong> Papers during conferences and symposium good and are primary sources e.g. literature</p>
<p><strong>Books:</strong> These are available in most libraries seek assistance of librarian to assist in library searching</p>
<p><strong>Abstracts:</strong> Abstracts give a list of journal articles with summaries e.g. nutritional abstracts</p>
<p><strong>Computer search:</strong> Can use key words in search for relevant literature</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>This is used where all information materials are computerized</p>
<p><strong>Internet</strong> One can browse the web and get literature from the latest articles, conference papers and policy documents from various organizations</p>
<p><strong>Others</strong> Includes periodicals, grey literature (unpublished literature) Africa etc</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="referencing-within-text">Referencing within text<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#referencing-within-text" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="african-psychological-association-apad-system">African psychological Association (APAD) system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#african-psychological-association-apad-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Method 1:</strong></p>
<p>Authors last name(s) and the year of document publication comes after or before paraphrased statements</p>
<p>a) e.g. Before (one author)</p>
<ul>
<li>John(2009) asserted that female condoms are only used by 2% of female students in the faculty of health sciences.</li>
</ul>
<p>Before (2 Authors)</p>
<p>John and Alice (2009) Asserted that female condoms are only used by 2% of female students in the faculty of health sciences in subsequent citation,</p>
<p>John, et al (2009) Asserted that...</p>
<p>b) After (one Author)</p>
<ul>
<li>It has been documented that only 2% of female students in the faculty of health sciences use female condoms( John,2009)</li>
</ul>
<p>After (two authors)</p>
<p>3 It has been documented that only 2% of female students in the F.H.S use female condoms(John and Alice (2009) )</p>
<p>4 After (three authors)</p>
<p>5 It has been documented that...(John, Alice and Kennedy, 2009) or John, et al, 2009</p>
<p><strong>Method 2: Numerical Referencing</strong></p>
<p>6 Here numbers are used instead of authors name year of publication e.g. It has been documented that only 2% of female students in the faculty of Health sciences use female condoms(1,2012) or the number can be put after the statement but no brackets</p>
<p><strong>Foot notes</strong></p>
<p>7 These are references which appear at the bottom of a journal paper or a book rather than at the end of the text.</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id=""><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"></span></h1></div>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>8 These serve two purposes</p>
<p>i. To provide additional information with no disruption
ii. To indicate the source of an idea. Are helpful to a reader who wish to refer to the sources of facts or opinions presented hence accurate and complete information is essential</p>
<p>9 Foot notes can be indicated through;</p>
<p>a) Numbering footnotes consecutively throughout the chapter and then put the references on each page
b) Footnotes can be numbered and then put at the end of the chapter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quotations">QUOTATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quotations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quotations may be used for several reasons;</p>
<p>i. For accuracy
ii. For presentation of statements that are unusually clear and well put
iii. To add strength to ones study especially when the quotation marks before and after the quote, then italiaze. E.g there is significant relationship between the alcohol intake and academic performance. The higher the alcohol intake, the lower the performance in academics. (Njenga, 2005)
iv. Direct quotation must be exactly the way it is (No corrections)</p>
<p>10 When using incomplete statements, use quotations marks before and after then quote, then italiaze, use 3 dots/periods to represent the missing text either before or after. E.g.</p>
<p>"...The higher the alcohol intake, the lower the performance in academics,"(Njenga,2005,P.5)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="cited-references-and-bibliography">Cited references and Bibliography<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cited-references-and-bibliography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Cited reference- Is the list of materials actually read and cited in the text by the researcher</p>
<p>Bibliography- Refers to the list of materials that were read whether in the text or not</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="examples-how-to-reference-different-sources-of-information">Examples how to reference different sources of information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-how-to-reference-different-sources-of-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Journal article (one author)</li>
</ol>
<p>Smanes, K.(1998), consumer issues and the elderly. Journal of consumer affairs, 24 235-244</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Journal article 9two authors)</li>
</ol>
<p>John, M. and Rose, N.(1976) effects of alcohol on reaction among truck drivers. Journal of gerontology,38.100-105</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Newspaper article</li>
</ol>
<p>Watoro Kamau (Aug 9th,1999) New campaign on child labour . the daily Nation PP.17</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>A book</li>
</ol>
<p>Harris, H. I(1986) why family estate planning? San Franscisco, CA Bankroft-Whitney company</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Journal Article from the web</li>
</ol>
<p>Herz, J.C.(1995,April) Surfing from the internet: A nethead's adventures online.(online senal)</p>
<p>Urban desires, 1.3,</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methodology">METHODOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methodology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Has to go about the particular design to use</li>
<li>This describes the procedures that have been followed in conducting the study</li>
<li>It deals with</li>
<li>i) Identifying research design</li>
<li>ii) Sampling procedures</li>
<li>iii) Measurement methods</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="research-design">RESEARCH DESIGN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#research-design" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Includes; common ones</p>
<p>a) Experimental- Classical or true quasi
b) Survey-A comparative study or correlation study
c) Descriptive research design
d) Case study design</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sample-and-sampling-methods">SAMPLE AND SAMPLING METHODS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-and-sampling-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is a subset or a small group that represents the total population of a study subscale, selected group, part at a whole</li>
<li>Population-Entire group of persons/ a set of objectives and events the research has to study</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-2-1-sampling-frame">5.2.1 Sampling frame<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-2-1-sampling-frame" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This document is available on
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>&gt; Is a comprehensive list of the sample element in the target population e.g. a list of all nurses in a district hospital</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-2-2-sampling-bias">5.2.2 Sampling bias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-2-2-sampling-bias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Occurs when the researcher has not carefully selected, the sample thatâ€™s expected to represent the target population</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-2-3-sampling-error">5.2.3 Sampling error<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-2-3-sampling-error" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Is the difference between the sample characteristics and population characteristics (population invalidity)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-2-4-sample-size">5.2.4 Sample size<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-2-4-sample-size" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; If time allows, a researcher should take a large sample which is better for generalization
&gt; It depends on factors such as;
&gt;   - Number of variables, type of research, design, method of data analysis, the size at the accessible population
&gt; It has been suggested that for coming up a sample size on estimation can be used.</p>
<p>E.g. for correlation studies 30 or more are required for descriptive signs and symptoms of accessible are enough for experimental at least 30 cases are required per group</p>
<p>NB: However thereâ€™s a statistical formula for calculating a sample size</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sampling-techniques">SAMPLING TECHNIQUES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sampling-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two basic sampling</p>
<p>a) Probability/random sampling
b) Non-probability sampling</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="probability-or-random-sampling">Probability or Random Sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#probability-or-random-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; The goal of probability sampling is to select a responsible number of subject, objects or cases that present to get population
&gt; In random sampling, each unit of the sample here have equal chance of being selected. This allows generation of results in a higher population</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-3-1-1-simple-random-sampling">5.3.1.1 Simple random sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-1-1-simple-random-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>It involves giving a number to every subject or a member of the accessible population placing the number in a container then picking any number at random
&gt; Alternatively one can use a table of random number or can be generated by computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-3-1-2-systematic-random-sampling">5.3.1.2 Systematic random sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-1-2-systematic-random-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; In every <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>k</mi><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> case is selected in a population frame for inclusion in the sample
&gt; The list of all members in the sampling frame, must be randomized to get a true random sample
&gt; Once the sampling frame has been randomized, the researcher then decides the sampling interval
&gt; Interval is the distance between the cases that are selected for the sample. i.e. divide the total population over sample size e.g. population of 400 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>K</mi><mtext>th</mtext></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>400</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>100</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K^{\text{th}} = 400 / 100 = 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">400/100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span> subject/case is used. Sample size at 60
&gt; Every <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> case is picked, this process continues and sampling case is completed</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-3-1-3-stratified-random-sampling">5.3.1.3 Stratified random sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-1-3-stratified-random-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; This ensures representation from various subgroups in the population
&gt; The population is subdivided into subgroups or statistics and the sample selected from each subgroup</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="steps">Steps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>a) Identify the population
b) Define the criteria for stratification e.g. sex, age, colour, gender, income level, cadres of nurses
c) Stratify the population into two or more groups using a given criteria have a list of population in each strata
d) Determine the required sample size and appropriate representation (can be proportionate or equal)
e) Select the respondent using simple random an appropriate number of subjects for each stratum</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-3-1-4-cluster-sampling">5.3.1.4 Cluster sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-1-4-cluster-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Used where sampling frame is not possible e.g. Where population is too large or if its scattered</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="steps">Steps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>S</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>a) Identify the population e.g. Malaria patients in Kenya
b) Define the clusters forming the population e.g. Malaria patients in district hospitals. Other clusters include ; schools, estate, ministries, department
c) Determine the required sample size e.g. Loss of malaria patients
d) List all the clusters in a random order e.g. Mombasa, Msambweni e.t.c
e) Using the table of random number select the required number of clusters according to size of cluster required e.g. Select 2-3 district hospital with loss of patients
f) All members in the selected cluster are included in the unit observed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-3-2-non-probability-sampling">5.3.2 Non probability sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-2-non-probability-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Used when a researcher is not interested in selecting a sample that is representative of a population</li>
<li>Is common in quantitative research because the focus is on depth information and not making references or generalizations</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-3-2-1-purposive-sampling">5.3.2.1 Purposive sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-2-1-purposive-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In this technique the researcher uses/selects cases that have the required information with one's object to the study</li>
<li>The cases are handpicked simply because they have the required information</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>N/B</strong></p>
<p>The researcher specifies the criteria e.g. certain age, range, region, education level, specified group etc</p>
<p><strong>Disadvantages include:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>â˜‘ Sampling bias</li>
<li>â˜‘ Non-representative hence no generalization</li>
<li>â˜‘ After the criteria has been set, random sampling is then applied</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-3-2-2-snow-balling-sampling">5.3.2.2 Snow balling sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-2-2-snow-balling-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In this method, initially the researcher identifies few subjects with desired characteristics using purposive method</li>
<li>This few respondent direct the researcher to other subject with similar characteristics</li>
<li>This continues until the researcher gets the number of cases/subjects he requires e.g. Research dealing with drug addicts and sex workers, social deviates</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>&gt; This method is useful where the population that possesses the required characteristics is small or hard to find</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-3-2-3-quota-sampling">5.3.2.3 Quota sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-2-3-quota-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Is similar to stratified random sampling and the objective is to include various groups or quota of the population in the study based on some criteria
&gt; Researcher purposely chooses the subject to fit the quota</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="steps">Steps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>a) Identify the population of interest
b) Determine size of sample
c) Stratify population into quota, depending on criteria
d) Cases are purposely selected to fill the quotas</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-3-2-4-convenient-accidental-sampling">5.3.2.4 Convenient/ Accidental sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-2-4-convenient-accidental-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Involves selecting cases or units of observation as they become available to the researcher, also called "volunteer sampling" e.g. if one wants to assess the BP on female on depo provera, once above 40 years, one will check the BP of any client on the age bracket of &gt;40 years who are attending FP clinic despite the parity, not everyone is given a chance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-conducting-a-pretest-pilot-study">5.8 CONDUCTING A PRETEST/PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-conducting-a-pretest-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Before you carry out the full scale data collection process, it is important to conduct a trial to see whether the instruments planned for collecting data are actually appropriate for the study and whether are collecting the information you need.
&gt; To achieve this, you have to carry out a pilot study/pretest
&gt; Pretest or pilot study is defined as;
&gt; - A small version of a proposed study conducted to refine the methodology or
&gt; - Is the process of carrying out preliminary study going through the entire research procedure with a small sample. Or
&gt; - Pretest refers to a small scale trial of a particular research component
&gt; In a pilot study, respondents chosen have characteristics to those to be used during the actual research
&gt; The settings should be almost similar</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-1-purposes-of-a-pre-test-pilot-study">5.8.1 PURPOSES OF A PRE-TEST/PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-1-purposes-of-a-pre-test-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A pilot study is done to;</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>i. To ensure that items in the data collection instruments are stated clearly and have the same meaning to all research respondents (Refine where necessary)
ii. To determine whether the proposed study is feasible
iii. To identify any problems with the research design
iv. To assess the time taken to administer the research instruments
v. To determine whether the sample is representative of the population
vi. To determine the effectiveness of the sampling technique used
vii. To give the researcher the real experience in the field (with the respondents, environment, methodology and instruments)
viii. Determine the human and financial resources requirement for the study
ix. Determine the effectiveness of the training given to research assistants where necessary
x. Evaluate the procedure for data process and analysis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-2-appropriate-time-to-conduct-a-pilot-study">5.8.2 APPROPRIATE TIME TO CONDUCT A PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-2-appropriate-time-to-conduct-a-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It should be conducted before the actual full-scale study.</li>
<li>The advantages of conducting the pre-test before finalizing the proposal is that one can draft the work plan and budget based on realistic estimates</li>
<li>Also one can revise the data collection tools he/she submits the proposal for approval</li>
<li>Can be done before or after training research assistants or immediately after</li>
<li>If it is not possible to do it in the above circumstances, e.g. the proposal being drafted far from the field or no similar research settings available close to the drafting site, the pretest can be done after finishing the proposal. However it should be done long before the actual field work to allow for a thorough revision of data collection tools.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-8-3-using-findings-of-the-pre-test-pilot-study">5.8.3 USING FINDINGS OF THE PRE-TEST/PILOT STUDY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-8-3-using-findings-of-the-pre-test-pilot-study" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Identify any sensitive or annoying items in the instrument and rectify them</li>
<li>Any question that interviewers had to repeat and explain several times to respondents need to be rectified</li>
<li>Analyze the results of this pre-test and develop dummy tables</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>UNIT THREE: DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-measurement-levels-and-tools-used-in-data-collection">5.4 MEASUREMENT LEVELS AND TOOLS USED IN DATA COLLECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-measurement-levels-and-tools-used-in-data-collection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-4-1-measurement-level-scales">5.4.1 Measurement level scales<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-measurement-level-scales" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Itâ€™s the process of assigning number to variables</li>
<li>Measurement as used in research implies quantification of information ie assigning some type of number to the data</li>
<li>These applies in quantitative research</li>
<li>Mathematical calculations that can be made with data obtained depend on the level/scale of measurement</li>
<li>There are 4 levels/scales of measurement</li>
<li>a) Nominal scale</li>
<li>b) Ordinal scale</li>
<li>c) Interval scale</li>
<li>d) Ratio scale</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-4-1-1-nominal-scale">5.4.1.1 Nominal scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-1-nominal-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Considered as the lowest level of measurement/scale of all variables</li>
<li>This level/scale merely groups subjects/cases from the sample into categories with a common set of characteristics</li>
<li>Variables that can only be measured at nominal level include:</li>
<li>Sex e.g. male and female</li>
<li>Marital status e.g. single, married, separated, divorced</li>
<li>Religion e.g. Christian, Islam, Hinduism, ATR e.g. variable marital status may be included in a research. The researcher then can operationalise this variable as married, single, divorced, separated</li>
<li>The researcher would then number the subjects that fall in (3) separated (4) these numbers are for identification e.g. married (40) single (10) divorced(5) separated(1) in a frequency.</li>
<li>Numbers are often assigned to various categories for the purpose of identification. We could have assigned 1-married, 2- single, 3-divorced, 4- separated</li>
<li>These numbers do not represent quantities or order, addition, subtraction, division, multiplication of this numbers would yield meaningless values.</li>
<li>Variables that can take two categories are referred to as â€œDichotomousâ€ e.g. sex can take either male and female</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-1-2-ordinal-scale">5.4.1.2 Ordinal scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-2-ordinal-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The scale groups subjects into categories and also ranks them into same order either ascending, descending (highest to lowest) or (lowest to highest)</li>
<li>Numerical represent relative position or order among the values of the variables
E.g. community health cadres (KECN, KRN, KRCHN, BSN, MSN, PHD)
Social economic class (low, mild, upper class)
Severity of anaemia (mild, moderate, severe)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-1-3-interval-scale">5.4.1.3 Interval scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-3-interval-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In this class, numbers assigned in each measure are ranked in order and interval between numbers are equal</li>
<li>Numerical used represent quantities in mathematical operations (+ve, -ve) on numerical would yield meaningful values but this mathematical operations are limited to addition and subtraction (multiplication and divisions are not applicable)</li>
<li>In this scale, thereâ€™s no true 0 point i.e. It can take-ve values e.g. interval scale measures include;
Temp. in test score or in foren height e.g. 99Â°C-98Â°C-98.2Â°C order and interval of 0.4Â°C.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-1-4-ratio-scale">5.4.1.4 Ratio scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-1-4-ratio-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is the highest level of measurement, itâ€™s the most precise method of measuring a variable</li>
<li>It has all characteristics of other scales (nominal, internal, ordinal)</li>
<li>It has a true 0 point and all mathematical operations can be applied to yield meaningful values</li>
<li>Most physical objects can be measured at the ratio scale e.g. Weight, height, age, area, BP, distance e.t.c. e.g. a field 1000m long is as twice as long as one which is 50m long. Therefore 0m long means no length as weight</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>NB</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>When considering interval and ratio scale, there are 2 types of variables
i. <strong>Discrete variable</strong>: these can take only exact numbers (whole numbers)
ii. <strong>Continuous variable</strong>: these measures can theoretically occur at any point in a continuous e.g. Height 5.2m, 5.65m, age 24.3years 34.8months</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-instruments-in-research">5.5 INSTRUMENTS IN RESEARCH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-instruments-in-research" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An ideal instrument is one which results in measurements that are relevant, accurate, objective, sensitive and efficient</li>
<li>An instrument is a device used to measure the concept of interest in a research project</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; Instruments can be;
i. Observation scales, forms or checklist
ii. Questionnaires
iii. Interview schedules
iv. Standardized tests</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-questionnaires">5.5.1 QUESTIONNAIRES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-questionnaires" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Itâ€™s the commonly used tool
&gt; Each item in the questionnaire is used to address a specific objective research question or hypothesis of the study
&gt; The researcher must know how each item in the questionnaire is to be analyzed
&gt; A questionnaire must be well thought or it will;
Cause a confusion to the respondent on the information required
Discourage the respondents to an extent of discarding it
It may leave important information</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-1-categories-of-questions-used-in-a-questionnaire">5.5.1.1 CATEGORIES OF QUESTIONS USED IN A QUESTIONNAIRE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-1-categories-of-questions-used-in-a-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-structural-or-close-ended">a) Structural or close ended<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-structural-or-close-ended" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>These are accompanied with possible alternatives from where respondents select the answer that will best describe the situation</li>
<li>Always has the other(specify) option to cater for any category that might have been left out eg. What do you crave for in pregnancy apart from food?</li>
<li>clay â€“ charcoal â€“ others (specify)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="disadvantages-of-structured-questions">Disadvantages of structured questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages-of-structured-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>They are more difficult to construct because categories must be well thought out</li>
<li>Responses are limited and the respondent is compelled to answer according to research choices</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="advantages-of-structured-questions">Advantages of structured questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-structured-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Are easy to analyze</li>
<li>Easy to administer because each item followed by alternative answers</li>
<li>Are economical in time and costs</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-unstructured-open-question">b) Unstructured / open question<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-unstructured-open-question" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>They give the respondent freedom of response</li>
<li>They have no present alternatives
E.g. how do you handle cases of malpractice? ...</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="advantages-of-open-ended-questions">Advantages of open ended questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-open-ended-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This document is available on
studocu
