<p>i. They yield in depth responses
ii. They are simpler to formulate because the researcher does not need to labour to come up with appropriate categories
iii. Responses give insight to the feelings, attitudes, interest, decisions, hidden motivations and background
iv. They stimulate persons to think about his feelings or motives and to express what he considers to be most important</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages">Disadvantages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Answers given might be irrelevant to the research objectives
ii. They are hard to categorize and analyze
iii. They are time consuming for respondents and may put them off.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-contingency-questions">c) Contingency questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-contingency-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Are applicable to certain respondents only and not all</li>
<li>These are follow up questions and are required to get further information from relevant subgroup also called â€˜filterâ€™ questions</li>
<li>They are used to probe for more information and save the respondent from answering questions which are irrelevant to them</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Have you ever been pricked by a needle?</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Yes.</li>
<li>No.</li>
<li>If yes how many times</li>
<li>Once.</li>
<li>2-4 times.</li>
<li>Over 4 times.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Have you ever used any contraceptives</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Yes.</li>
<li>No.</li>
<li>The questions can be structured or unstructured</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-matrix-questions">c) Matrix questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-matrix-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>These are questions that share same set of response categories</li>
<li>Are common whenever scales are used</li>
<li>Examples how are you satisfied with you job?</li>
<li>a) Financial 12345</li>
<li>b) Quality of life 12345</li>
<li>c) Level of assets 12345</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>d) Ability to save 12345</p>
<p><strong>Key</strong></p>
<p>1- Extremely dissatisfied
2- Dissatisfied
3- Neutral
4- Satisfied
5- Extremely satisfied</p>
<p><strong>Advantages of matrix questions</strong></p>
<p>a) They are easy to complete and unlikely to put off respondents
b) Space is used efficiently
c) It is easy to compare responses given to different items. The researcher can easily detect a trend just by glancing at the responses
d) They are easy to analyze</p>
<p><strong>Disadvantages of matrix questions</strong></p>
<p>a) Because they are easy to construct and analyze they can be misused
b) Some respondents may form a pattern of agreeing or disagreeing with all items</p>
<p><strong>5.5.1.2 RULES FOR CONSTRUCTING A QUESTIONNAIRE AND ITS ITEMS</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Start by listing the specific objectives that you want the questionnaire to accomplish</li>
<li>Determine how each item is to be analyzed</li>
<li>Ensure clarity avoid terms like â€˜mostâ€™ or several</li>
<li>If a concept has several meanings, then the intended meaning must be defined</li>
<li>Short questions are preferred to long ones</li>
<li>Items should be stated positively as much as possible. Negative words are easily overlooked by respondents</li>
<li>Questions with two separate items should be avoided</li>
<li>Leading or biased questions should be avoided</li>
<li>Very personal and sensitive questions should be avoided</li>
<li>Use simple words that are easy to understand</li>
<li>Avoid psychologically threatening questions eg. Are you worried of the consequences of divorce?</li>
<li>Avoid questions that assume facts without evidence</li>
<li>Make complete meaningful statements</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>5.5.1.3 PRETESTING A QUESTIONNAIRE</strong></p>
<p>6 This is trying out the questionnaire in the field</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>7 It should be tried to sample which is similar to the actual selected sample. Subject in the actual sample should not be used in the pretest
8 The pretest sample should be 1%-10% of the sample size</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reasons-for-pretest">Reasons for pretest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reasons-for-pretest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Vague questions will be revealed as the respondents will interpret them differently
ii. Other deficiencies will be revealed e.g. unclear instructions, limited space, wrong numbering
iii. Comments and suggestions from the respondents during pretest will improve the questionnaire if incorporated
iv. Because few questions are analyzed, the method of analysis appropriateness is tested</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-1-4-ways-of-administering-a-questionnaire">5.5.1.4 WAYS OF ADMINISTERING A QUESTIONNAIRE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-1-4-ways-of-administering-a-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-self-administered-questionnaire">a) Self administered questionnaire<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-self-administered-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Respondents fill questionnaires themselves which can be sent to them by mail or by hand delivery</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-researcher-administered-by-questionnaire">b) Researcher administered by questionnaire<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-researcher-administered-by-questionnaire" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcher interviews the respondents using a questionnaire</li>
<li>This is applicable when the respondents may not have the ability to interpret the questions because of their educational levels</li>
<li>Questions are read out to the respondents and their options/choices are written down</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-using-internet">c) Using internet<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-using-internet" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sampling and collection of data is done through the internet and responses are given via e-mail or website.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-2-interview-schedule">5.5.2 INTERVIEW SCHEDULE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-2-interview-schedule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a set of questions that the interview asks when interviewing</li>
<li>It is used to orally obtain data from the respondent</li>
<li>Cooperation is key to good results. Good rapport is a must</li>
<li>Questions in the interview schedule can be structured or unstructured</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages-of-interview">Advantages of Interview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages-of-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. In depth data is obtained which cannot be obtained with questionnaires
ii. It is precise in attaining specific objectives
iii. There is no confusion as the interviewer can clarify the questions
iv. It is more flexible than questionnaires</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>v. Can capture very sensitive and personal information by honest and personal interaction between the researcher and respondents
vi. You can get more information by probing
vii. Can also expose negative responses through interaction and genuine conversation
viii. There is high response rate because it is not easy to refuse to answer questions or completely ignore the researcher.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages">Disadvantages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Interview are expensive as time, travelling to meet respondents is costly.
ii. It calls for high level communication and interpersonal skills. Which some researcher may lack
iii. There could be interviews bias hence need training to avoid bias
iv. The interview may be subjective in that the subjects may be too eager to please the researcher. Again the researcher may ask questions to support his perceived notions
v. Because it is time consuming, the researcher may be forced to use a small sample
vi. Respondents may have bias/prejudice. E.g. affluent researcher going to a poor community may influence the respondent's reaction</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-2-1-data-collection-during-interview">5.5.2.1 DATA COLLECTION DURING INTERVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-2-1-data-collection-during-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Data can be collected by;</p>
<p>i. Note taking- where the researcher takes notes as the subjects answer questions asked. Should be done carefully not to upset the respondent. Responses should be recorded the way they are expressed
ii. Tape recording- responses are recorded in a video or a tape recorder. One should be careful when recording.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-3-standardized-tests">5.5.3 STANDARDIZED TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-3-standardized-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A standardized test is one that has consistency and uniform procedures for administering scoring and interpreting the behavior of the subjects. E.g. 1Q intelligence tests</li>
<li>Graduate record examination (GRE) usually by students wishing to pursue further studies abroad</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-5-4-observation-forms-schedules-or-checklists">5.5.4 OBSERVATION FORMS SCHEDULES OR CHECKLISTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-4-observation-forms-schedules-or-checklists" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>These are used to record what the researcher observes during data collection</li>
<li>The behaviours to be observed must be defined. The observer checks off each observed behavior as they occur</li>
<li>Sometimes rating scales are used, responses are recorded and evaluated</li>
<li>Can be used by;</li>
<li>Non participant observer or</li>
</ul>
