<p>Participant observer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7-0-data-analysis-and-presentation">7.0 DATA ANALYSIS AND PRESENTATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-0-data-analysis-and-presentation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-1-qualitative-data-presentation-and-analysis">7.1 QUALITATIVE DATA PRESENTATION AND ANALYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-1-qualitative-data-presentation-and-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Data presentation and analysis of qualitative research is quite different from data collected when using quantitative methods</li>
<li>This is because qualitative research uses words while quantitative uses numbers</li>
<li>The following steps could be used when presenting and analyzing qualitative data:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-1-1-organizing-the-data">1.1.1 Organizing the data<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-1-organizing-the-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The data collected is usually large, therefore the researcher will need to put all this information in a simple format. This is called "clearing" the data</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-1-2-creating-categories-themes-and-patterns">1.1.2 Creating categories; themes and patterns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-2-creating-categories-themes-and-patterns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The disorganized and fragmented data needs to be put into categories, themes and patterns. One can use research questions or discussion topics</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-1-3-analyzing-and-interpreting-the-data">1.1.3 Analyzing and interpreting the data<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-3-analyzing-and-interpreting-the-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Once themes, categories and patterns have been identified, the researcher then evaluates the data to determine its usefulness and accuracy. Computer programmes can be used to generate themes and categories</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-1-4-writing-the-report">1.1.4 Writing the report<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-4-writing-the-report" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Unlike in quantitative research where the report writing is done after analyzing the data, in quantitative research techniques, the report writing and the analysis go hand in hand</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-2-quantitative-data-presentation-and-analysis">1.2 QUANTITATIVE DATA PRESENTATION AND ANALYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-2-quantitative-data-presentation-and-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="7-2-1-descriptive-statistics">7.2.1 Descriptive statistics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-1-descriptive-statistics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the process of organizing, summarizing and visualizing quantitative data</li>
<li>The purpose of descriptive statistics is to help the researcher to visualize and identify the patterns that may emerge from the data collected. This in turn assists the researcher in making meaningful conclusions from the results of the study.</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Type of statistics or indices used depend on type of variable and scale of measurement (Nominal, ordinal, interval, or rational)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="main-types-of-descriptive-statistics">Main types of descriptive statistics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#main-types-of-descriptive-statistics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-2-1-1-measures-of-central-tendency">1.2.1.1 Measures of central tendency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-2-1-1-measures-of-central-tendency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Measures of central tendency (mean, mode, median) are statistics that describe the average, typical or most common value for a group of data
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> A measure of central tendency summarizes a frequency distribution by the use of a single number
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> There are 3 main types of commonly used measures of central tendency</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-the-mode">a. The mode<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-the-mode" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Def: This is the most commonly occurring value or category among a sample of subjects
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> This is the only measure of central tendency appropriate for nominal data. Mode may also be reported for ordinal, interval or ratio
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> A set of data with one value that occurs most frequently is unimodal. Two is biomodal and if more than two values occurring more frequently it is multimodal. It is possible to have no mode. 358991011 9=mode</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-the-median">b. The median<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-the-median" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> This is the score that divides ranked scores into two equal parts, such that half of the scores are larger than the median and the other half are smaller
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Median is appropriate for ordinal, interval and ratio data influenced by extreme values. Media is frequently used in reporting average income because extreme values do not affect the median.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-mean">c. Mean<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-mean" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> This means the average of a set of scores or measurements
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> It is most frequently used measure of central tendency,
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> Is arrived at by adding all values and dividing by the total number of values
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>â‹„</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\diamond</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">â‹„</span></span></span></span></span> The mean is appropriate for interval and ratio data</p>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>It is the most stable measure of central tendency for these levels of data if the distribution is normal
If the distribution is not normal and extreme values are present, the mean will not represent an accurate picture of the distribution.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-2-2-measures-of-variability-measures-dispersion">7.2.2.2 Measures of variability (measures dispersion)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-2-2-measures-of-variability-measures-dispersion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Measures of variability described how spreads out values are a distribution of values. Variability is the distribution of scores around a particular central score or value (usually the mean)
Although measures of central tendency are important, sometimes it may be interesting to know how spreads out the values are in the distribution.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="for-example">For example<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The following are pulse rates of subjects 2 groups (A and B)</p>
<p>Group A-80,79,78,78,75 mean 390/5=78</p>
<p>Group B- 100,90,80,70,50 mean 390/5=78</p>
<p>For this example, the pulse rates for both is 78. However the pulse of group A seems homogeneous, or alike, while group B are heterogeneous, or dissimilar. This information is very important because the arithmetic mean is not appropriate to use in describing group B or to use in comparing the two groups of pulse rates</p>
<p>The most common measures of variability are range, standard deviation, variance, percentile and 2-5 scores</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-measures-of-variability">Types of measures of variability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-measures-of-variability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-range">i. Range<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-range" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the difference between the highest and the lowest value in the group of values or scores in a distribution</li>
<li>This is determined by subtracting the lowest value from the highest score. E.g scores 78,79,80,81,82,85. The range is 85-78</li>
<li>A small range signifies that scores are not spread out and vice versa</li>
<li>Range is used to gain a quick picture of the dispersion of data. Range has limited usefulness because one extreme score can change the range drastically</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-standard-deviation-and-the-variance">ii. Standard deviation and the variance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-standard-deviation-and-the-variance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Standard deviation is defined as the extent to which scores I a distribution deviate from their mean average</li>
<li>The standard deviation therefore involves subtracting the mean from each score to obtain the deviation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-2-3-frequency-distribution">7.2.2.3 Frequency distribution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-2-3-frequency-distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is one of the simplest ways to present data</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>&gt; Frequencies are obtained by simply counting the occurrences of values or scores represented in the data
&gt; Frequency distribution are appropriate for reporting all level of data (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio)
&gt; In a frequency distribution, all values or scores are listed and the number of times each appears is recorded
&gt; Values may be listed from the highest to the lowest or vice versa
&gt; Use slash method(////) and if range is small, say less than 20, each score may be listed individually
&gt; Groups of scores must be exhaustive (include all possible values) and mutually exclusive (no overlapping of categories) e.g.</p>
<p>pulse rate tally frequency
60-65 /// 3
66-70 /// 5
71-75 /// // 7/15</p>
<p>&gt; Frequency distributions may be described according to their shape
&gt; They can be symmetrical or non-symmetrical
&gt; Symmetrical distributions are those in which both values of the distribution are the same
&gt; Non-symmetrical distribution also called skewed are those in which distribution has an off-centre peak
&gt; Skewness - is a measure of horizontal departure from normal distribution. it can be positive skew or negative skew
&gt;   Positive skew - is where the tail of the measures of a particular variable are low with very few high measures
&gt;   Negative skew - is where the tail of the distribution points to the left i.e. the majority of the scores/measures of a variable are very high and very few low measures</p>
<p>&gt; A variable that tends to be positively skewed is personal income while few earn large income. An example of a negatively skewed distribution would be age of people who have chronic illnesses. (a few young and middle aged men and women have chronic illnesses, but many elderly people have chronic conditions.</p>
<p>&gt; A part from skewness, another deviation from the standard normal curve is kurtosis - is the vertical departure from the normal
&gt; This is the peakedness or the flatness of a curve
&gt; A curve that is peaked is called leptokurtic
&gt; A relatively flat curve is said to be platykurtic. The kurtosis of the standard curve lies between the two extreme and is called mesokurtic.</p>
<p>This document is available on
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>7.2.2.4 Characteristics of a Normal curve</p>
<ol>
<li>It is well shaped with symmetrical distribution and the maximum height being the mean</li>
<li>The mean, median, and mode are the same</li>
<li>Most values cluster around the mean</li>
<li>T</li>
<li>The tails of the curve never touch the base because the distribution is theoretical, rather than empirical
N/B : normal distribution is frequently found in many happenings in nature. Height and weight are normally distributed in the population</li>
</ol>
<p>7.2.3 GRAPHIC PRESENTATION OF FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION</p>
<ul>
<li>A graph enables the reader to see the trend of the distribution easily than is possible by simply looking at numbers in a frequency distribution</li>
<li>A graph should be labeled on both the vertical and horizontal axes. It should also have a title</li>
<li>Graphs commonly used to present data in research reports include: histograms, frequency polygons, and bar charts.</li>
</ul>
<p>7.2.3.1 Histograms</p>
<ul>
<li>Histograms consists of a series of adjacent bars whose x-axis represent the number of subjects obtaining a particular score, number of respondents belonging to a particular category. X-axis usually has the scores</li>
<li>Exact limits are commonly used to construct a histogram hence the bars are continuous with no space in between</li>
</ul>
<p>Example below is a distribution scores from a test..</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Score limits</th><th>exact limits</th><th>frequency (f)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>91-100</td><td>90.5-100.5</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td>81-90</td><td>80.5-90.5</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>71-80</td><td>70.5-80.5</td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>61-70</td><td>60.5-70.5</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>51-60</td><td>50.5-60.5</td><td>14</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>N=34</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Figure 1. Histogram derived from the score above</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-3-1-frequency-polygons">7.2.3.1 Frequency polygons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-3-1-frequency-polygons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A polygon is a many-sided figure. To plot a frequency polygon, one must establish the midpoint of the class interval</li>
<li>The midpoint is established by summing up the lower and upper class limits of each interval then divide by 2. The midpoint are then plotted against the frequencies and the points are joined using straight lines</li>
<li>A frequency polygon is a closed figure and so the ends meet the horizontal line one limit after the highest and score and one unit from the lowest score</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Table 2: Distribution of scores from</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Scores</th><th>Midpoints</th><th>Frequency</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10-20</td><td>15</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>20-30</td><td>25</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>30-40</td><td>35</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>40-50</td><td>45</td><td>5</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Figure 2: Frequency polygon constructed from data in table 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-3-2-bar-charts">7.2.3.2 Bar charts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-3-2-bar-charts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Bar charts are preferred when data is discrete or categorized or when the scale is nominal.</li>
<li>This is because the categories in a nominal scale do not imply any order</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Bar chart is very similar to the histogram except that spaces are left between the bars to signify a lack of continuity or flow between the categories</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Table 3: Department enrolment</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Subject category</th><th>frequency(f)</th><th>%frequency</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Biology</td><td>5</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>Maths</td><td>20</td><td>40</td></tr><tr><td>Geography</td><td>20</td><td>40</td></tr><tr><td>History</td><td>5</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>N=50</td><td>100</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Fig.3: Bar chart based on data presented in table 9</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-3-4-choosing-a-graph">7.2.3.4 Choosing a graph<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-3-4-choosing-a-graph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For discrete variables a bar chart is better</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Frequency polygons have an advantage that several polygons can be superimposed with less crossing of lines</li>
<li>This allows for comparisons among various distributions</li>
<li>Histograms are easier to understand especially when only one distribution is being represented</li>
<li>However, histograms give the impression that subjects fitting within each interval are evenly distributed over the interval which is not always the case</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-3-5-percentages">7.2.3.5 Percentages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-3-5-percentages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A percentage is defined as the proportion of a subgroup to the total group or sample and range from 0% to 100%</li>
<li>The size of the total group on which percentages is useful or valid should be big. A minimum number should be at least 20</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>UNIT FOUR: ETHICAL ISSUES IN RESEARCH</p>
<ul>
<li>Issues of ethical behavior are central to health professions</li>
<li>In conducting clinical trials and research projects, ethical issues should be taken into consideration</li>
<li>It is unethical for an investigator not to give patients the best possible treatment</li>
<li>Other way, it is unethical not to discover whether a new treatment is an improvement, since this would deny future patients the possibility of a cure.</li>
<li>It is also unethical to perform bad trials that give misleading results and there by encourage others not to use a treatment that is beneficial or to use a treatment that is not beneficial, or may indeed have harmful effects</li>
<li>Two important areas of ethical consideration are</li>
<li>rights of human subjects and</li>
<li>freedom from harm</li>
<li>Three factors are important regarding the rights of the participants</li>
<li>Confidentiality</li>
<li>Anonymity</li>
<li>Voluntary participation</li>
<li>It can be ensured through an informed consent which clearly explains the study objectives and states participation right to accept or refuse to participate</li>
</ul>
<p>2.6.1 Research participants at Risk</p>
<ul>
<li>Research participants at risk are individuals who may be harmed physically emotionally, spiritually, socially or legally through participation in a research study</li>
<li>A basic responsibility of the researcher and those assisting in carrying out the project, is to protect all research participants from harm and</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>while they are participating in an investigation or as a result of the study.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-2-informed-consent">2.6.2 Informed consent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-2-informed-consent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Informed consent is the process of providing an individual with sufficient understandable information regarding his or her participation in a research project</li>
<li>It includes providing potential participants with information about their rights and responsibilities within the project and documenting the nature of the agreement</li>
<li>All consent forms need to assure potential participants of their right to withdraw from a research study at any time. Informed consent is the researchers conscious and deliberate attempt to clearly and fully provide the potential participant with information about the study</li>
<li>It is a fundamental responsibility of the investigator in human research to ensure research participants understand the nature of the project and the implications of participation and the individual is able to decide freely whether to participate in a project, without fear of reprisal. When the researcher fails to adequately inform potential research participants about full nature of the research, thereby preventing them from making an informed decision on their participation is called deception</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-3-confidentiality-and-anonymity">2.6.3 Confidentiality and Anonymity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-3-confidentiality-and-anonymity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcherâ€™s responsibility to protect all data gathered within the scope of the project from being divulged to othersâ€”confidentiality</li>
<li>Anonymity Refers to the act of keeping individuals nameless in relation to their participation in a research project</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-4-regulatory-bodies">2.6.4 Regulatory Bodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-4-regulatory-bodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcher may need to take permission from regulatory bodies for conducting research investigations, mainly when subjects are human beings</li>
<li>These are regulatory bodies in most of the countries which grant permission after considering ethical issues of study</li>
<li>National council for science and technology deals with approval and authorization of research being done in Kenya.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-5-misuse-of-privileges">2.6.5 Misuse of privileges<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-5-misuse-of-privileges" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>S</p>
<p>studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> Researchers have power over their subjects to their training, legal authority to undertake research, and their perceived ability to provide help. Subjects therefore participate in research based on this trust.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> It is therefore unethical for researchers to abuse this trust by using their powers negatively e.g.
&gt; Using obtained data to stigmatize or indict the same subjects
&gt; Doing research in pretext of providing help</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-6-use-of-vulnerable-and-special-groups">2.6.6 Use of vulnerable and /special groups<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-6-use-of-vulnerable-and-special-groups" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> Consent should be obtained in case of disadvantaged from their guardians
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> These groups include:
&gt; Mentally challenged sick people, children
&gt; Prisoners, street children e.t.c.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-7-financial-issues-and-sponsored-research">2.6.7 Financial issues and sponsored research<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-7-financial-issues-and-sponsored-research" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> A sponsor may demand compromise on quality to save on costs and time
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> Some sponsors may demand the findings to be reported in a distorted manner for their own selfish reasons
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> Some researchers may divert research funds for their own use
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> All these are unacceptable. A researcher should maintain his/her integrity</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-8-dissemination-of-findings">2.6.8 Dissemination of Findings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-8-dissemination-of-findings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> It is unethical to conceal research findings for some reasons. Even if results are contrary or against the sponsorâ€™s wishes or expectations, they should be disseminated and not concealed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-9-intellectual-property-rights">2.6.9 Intellectual property Rights<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-9-intellectual-property-rights" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> Joint researchers should not be published as personal by one individual.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-6-10-plagiarism-and-fraud">2.6.10 Plagiarism and Fraud<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-10-plagiarism-and-fraud" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Plagiarism;</strong>
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">âœ“</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">âœ“</span></span></span></span></span> Is a situation where a researcher refers to another persons work as his/her without acknowledging the author this is punishable by law</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Fraud:</p>
<p>âœ“ Is where a researcher takes data that has not actually been collected and also false presentation of research methodology and results.
âœ“ This is also punishable in law</p>
<p>UNIT FIVE: RESEARCH FINDINGS, DISSEMINATION AND REPORT WRITING</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-0-communicating-the-research-findings">8.0 COMMUNICATING THE RESEARCH FINDINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-0-communicating-the-research-findings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The significance of conducting research is to communicate and share the research findings.</li>
<li>There are several ways of communicating research findings.</li>
<li>These are:-</li>
<li>i. A written report for academic purposes e.g. thesis or desertion which are requirements for obtaining a certain academic level</li>
<li>ii. A written report prepared for some managers and policy implementersâ€”present a clear and detailed report with no academic jargons</li>
<li>iii. A written report sent as an article for publication in referred/non-referred journals</li>
<li>iv. Presentation of the research findings in workshops, seminars and conferences</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-1-presenting-research-results-at-professional-conferences">8.1 PRESENTING RESEARCH RESULTS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-1-presenting-research-results-at-professional-conferences" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Because publication in journals which is referred takes long (up to 3 years), presentation of research findings is more rapid in distribution of study results</li>
<li>Presentation should be in community health conferences as well as interdisciplinary conferences</li>
<li>Research results can be presented at professional conferences in two ways</li>
<li>a) Oral presentation</li>
<li>b) Poster presentationâ€” has become more popular</li>
<li>Potential participants are contacted through â€œcall for abstractsâ€</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>The call for abstracts is a request for a summary for a study that the researcher wishes to present at a conference</p>
<p>These requests are published in professional journals and distributed to educational institutions, health care agencies and potential participants from professional organizations notices of research</p>
<p>Conferences are generally distributed 6-12 months before the event.</p>
<p>Each conference or seminar provide guidelines for presenters and for submission of abstracts</p>
<p>Abstract length varies from 50-1000 words, but many have 200-300 word limitations</p>
<p>It contains the purpose, research question(s), hypothesis, design, methodology, major findings and conclusions</p>
<p>Generally, those selected to participate receive no pay and are required to cover their own travel expenses</p>
<p>In some cases conference registration fee is waived or reduced for participants</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-2-presenting-a-research-paper">8.2 PRESENTING A RESEARCH PAPER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-2-presenting-a-research-paper" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An oral presentation of a research report is usually referred to as paper presentation. Paper because it has been written on paper and is read by the investigator.</p>
<p>If principal investigator is unable to attend the conference, a co-investigator or another person familiar with the study presents the paper.</p>
<p>Presenting research results at a conference has advantages</p>
<p>i. The researcher presents findings that are current/recent unlike publication that lags behind for up to 3 years</p>
<p>ii. The researcher has an opportunity to interact with those people who are interested in the study and will be able to locate other researchers who are studying the same or similar phenomena</p>
<p>The presenter is usually given 10-15 minutes. Sometimes additional time is allocated for questions or during break, other questions are dealt with.</p>
<p>Format for oral presentation is the same as that of the journal but condensation of material is done to fit the time given.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-0-writing-research-reports">12.0 WRITING RESEARCH REPORTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-0-writing-research-reports" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The research report contains:</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>&gt; Title
&gt; Dedication (optional)
&gt; Abstract
&gt; Table of contents
&gt; List of tables
&gt; List of figures
&gt; List of abbreviation and acronyms
&gt; Executive summary (optional)
&gt; Introduction
&gt; Literature review
&gt; Methodology
&gt; Results and discussion
&gt; Summary, conclusions and recommendations
&gt; References
&gt; Acknowledgement
&gt; Appendices</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-1-title">12.1 TITLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-1-title" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Should be short and simple - 12-15 words maximum</li>
<li>Should contain key words that others will use when searching the topic</li>
<li>It gives the reader some initial information about the area of research the report has covered</li>
<li>It should give the major variables of the research, the target population and possibly the geographical location e.g. the research</li>
<li>It is the selling point as it will determine whether someone will read your article</li>
<li>The authorship must be only</li>
<li>Someone who contributed to the design, data collection, analysis or interpretation of the findings</li>
<li>Contributed to the writing or editing of the final manuscript</li>
<li>Agrees with the findings and is willing to stand up in public and defend the work</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-2-dedication-optional">12.2 Dedication (optional)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-2-dedication-optional" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Some researchers dedicate their work to persons whom they see as special to their lives</li>
</ul>
<p>This document is available on
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>May be spouse, children, parents or very dear friends</li>
<li>Some researchers give reasons for their dedication</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-3-abstract">12.3 Abstract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-3-abstract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is a reflection of the salient findings of the research study (it is an overview)</li>
<li>It contains purpose of the study, the population studied, major results and conclusion of the study</li>
<li>Should not be more than half a page</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-4-table-of-contents">12.4 Table of contents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-4-table-of-contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A table of contents is like a map that guides reader in locating various sections of the research report</li>
<li>It contains the chapter teaching, main headings and subheadings and corresponding page of each in the body of the document</li>
<li>It is necessary for location of desired section quickly</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-5-list-of-tables">12.5 List of tables<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-5-list-of-tables" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This list of tables has a format like that of the table of contents.</li>
<li>The number and title of each table appearing in the body of report is listed together with corresponding page number</li>
<li>Used for easy tracing of tables</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-6-list-of-figures">12.6 List of figures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-6-list-of-figures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Figures such as graphs, charts, diagrams and photographs may be used in research</li>
<li>Their list as they appear in the body of the report</li>
<li>The list should clearly give the number and title of the figure and its number</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-7-list-of-abbreviations-and-acronyms">12.7 List of abbreviations and acronyms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-7-list-of-abbreviations-and-acronyms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>These abbreviations are used especially where a ward or a group of words is used repeatedly</li>
<li>The abbreviations and acronyms should be listed and explained in full</li>
<li>They should be used only when necessary</li>
<li>Refer on guidelines on use of abbreviations</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-8-executive-summary-advisable-to-include">12.8 Executive summary (Advisable to include)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-8-executive-summary-advisable-to-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is short version or a summary of the research report provides a picture of the entire document</li>
</ul>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>A good executive summary begins with a clear and brief statement of the problem
Details from the body of the report are then presented in brief and the summary ends with conclusions and recommendations
Use of bulletins and bolded subheading helps to make summary reader-friendly
Avoid technical terms in the executive summary</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-9-introduction">12.9 Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-9-introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This has several components that include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The background of the study</li>
<li>The problem statement</li>
<li>Objectives</li>
<li>Hypotheses</li>
<li>Research questions</li>
<li>Limitations of the study</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-10-literature-review">12.10 Literature Review<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-10-literature-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This provides the needed support to the researcher rationale for undertaking research in a certain area
The critique of findings from other studies done in related areas
Literature review assists the researcher in making a strong care for the study's objectives, research questions or hypotheses
Literature review should be relevant to the topic</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-11-methodology">12.11 Methodology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-11-methodology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It gives regarding the procedures used in conducting the study.
Issues discussed under methodology include the population, sample, sampling techniques, the research design, instruments or tools used in data collection, measurement of variables and techniques to be used in such tests
Give enough details regarding the procedures used in conducting the study should be precise enough to enable other researchers to replicate your study</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-12-results-and-discussion">12.12 Results and Discussion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-12-results-and-discussion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Main purpose of the results and discussion is to present the results of the data analysis in a systematic way</p>
<p>This document is available on
S
studocu
Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>The data analysis is done figures and tables are usually used
Computers and statistical packages has made data analysis easier and faster
In this section, it is advisable to start with a short introduction that describes the general procedure followed in analyzing the data
State the objectives or hypothesis of the study
Key pointers on writing the results and discussion are
âœ“ Present descriptive results of analysis first. They include frequencies, percentages, means, modes, median, and standard deviation e.t.c.
âœ“ Then present the results of hypotheses tests if any. These tests inform whether results can be generalized to the target population
âœ“ It may not be possible to present every result of the analysis. Select the most important findings for reporting. Be guided by objectives and hypotheses
âœ“ Not every result or table generated is presented in the report objectives and hypotheses of the study should guide you to select the most important ones
âœ“ Graphs, charts and other usual presentations of the data should be included in the results and discussion section of the report if they add value to the content
âœ“ It is very important for the researcher to point out whether findings are supported by other studies discussed in the literature review section. If findings contradict other studies, point out giving possible reasons for such outcome
The discussion section therefore conveys the meaning of the findings to the reader and provides an important linkage to other sections or components of the report such as objectives, hypotheses, research questions or theoretical/framework and existing literature</p>
<p>12.13 Summary, conclusions and recommendations</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<ul>
<li>Summary reminds and informs the reader about the purpose of study, process used to collect and analyze data and the major findings of the study</li>
<li>A summary must reflect as accurately as possible the body of one's report.</li>
<li>Conclusion: answers the questions that sparked the collection and analysis of data</li>
<li>In including the report, it is necessary to discuss the practical application and implications of the findings...</li>
<li>Implications: are usually targeted to stakeholders e.g. health policy makers</li>
<li>The summary and conclusions should lead logically to your recommendations must be consistent with the purpose of the study, its objectives, the evidence presented by the data and interpretations given</li>
<li>Recommendations should be practical and achievable</li>
<li>Common recommendations that researchers often make include:</li>
<li>Areas of further research, with the question in that study that remain unanswered, hence ought to be explored further</li>
<li>Methodology issues, that could be addressed and refined to improve future research in that area of the study</li>
<li>Actions that should be taken to address the problem based on the research findings e.g. interventions/projects</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-14-references">12.14 References<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-14-references" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The researcher should give credit to authors of any work or materials quoted from or rejected to by listing them</li>
<li>Generally, a reference gives the name of the author, year of publication of the document, the title of the book or journal paper and the publisher</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-15-acknowledgement">12.15 Acknowledgement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-15-acknowledgement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This document is available on</p>
<p>s  studocu</p>
<p>Downloaded by Birosoft Enterprises (<a href="mailto:birosoftenterprises@gmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">birosoftenterprises@gmail.com</a>)</p>
<p>Research process takes a lot of time, money and energy. A researcher may seek help from professional colleagues, respondents, research assistants etc.
One can also seek materials from institutions or organizations
The researcher should acknowledge individuals and organizations that provide assistance
But because they can be many, the researcher should maintain only a few by names to keep the acknowledgement section as short as possible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-16-appendices">12.16 Appendices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-16-appendices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The appendix section of the report contains information that the researcher does not seem necessary to include in the body of the report
The appendix contents include:-</p>
<ul>
<li>Instruments of data collection</li>
<li>Statistical tables from data analysis</li>
<li>Correspondence related to the study e.g. letters of consent to participate in the study</li>
<li>Letters of approval to conduct the research</li>
<li>Research persists and terms of reference if any.</li>
</ul>
